I can hand hold the camera with one hand with my arm fully extended to get a self-portrait of my self at 1/2 of a second with almost no blur. So I use manual exposure mode to manually set shutter speed.11) Anemic flash. Doesn't provide sufficient power to act as a fill flash on sunny days. Lower shutter speed to augment the flash power as outlined earlier.

Reviews.Title: Best deal for your money
Reviews.Author: Ben
Reviews.Content: I bought this one with Amazon for my wife a month ago. So I compared the photos with those of my Canon 40D. I must say that I can't tell the difference. Embarrassed isn't it?You probably know that a new model called ZS8 comes out this month (March 2011) to replace this ZS7. My advice is buy the ZS7 and save you $100 or more without feeling ambivalent. Here's why:1 Megapixels is a marketing ploy. 12 in this case is more than enough. Other components such as the size of the sensor and the quality of the lens are just as important. What if I give you a fancy title like Senior Executive Vice President and you only make $8 an hour!2. Zoom range - The ZS7 has the most practical range. My experience says the 25 wide angle is much more important than 300 mm. Any zoom beyond 12 times (or 300 equivalent) is silly. Don't forget that the larger the zoom, the more distorted the image will become.3. GPS -The newer model ZS8 gives you 1 million GPS locations instead of half a million with the ZS7. But I wonder if you spend a lot of money and time on your favorite vacation spot, why would you forget the name of the place where the photos are taken? It's more to do with senior moment! Plus, if you don't shut off the GPS feature, it's still on even if you turn off the camera. That will drain the battery. This is an example of high-tech bragging right that has nothing to do with enhancing your photo skill. It's like the 8-speed transmission in expensive automobiles, which won't make your 5 or 6 speed any less efficient.4. Video: The quality is way more than enough for Youtube or sharing with friends and family members - unless you plan to go to the Sundance festival.Folks, I used to pay $650 plus tax for an Olympus 5-meg model with horrible delay in 2003. This one is truly light years ahead. By the way Consumer Report puts Panasonic digital cameras on top of the reliability index. You enjoy Leica lens quality too.Final word: Don't get obsessed with high-tech features you don't need. Spend more time on improving your photo skill instead. Between you and me, even my wife agrees. Is that an achivement for me or what?

Reviews.Title: Excellent point-and-shoot, with some flaws
Reviews.Author: Douglas A. Hughey
Reviews.Content: I am over all very impressed with this camera.  My frame of reference is a couple of Canon Powershot A-series cameras that are a few years old (a530 and a710 IS) and a Canon Rebel XS DSLR camera.Features-Pros:  This camera has tons of features, starting with a great wide-angle (which has really impressed me with its ability to get so much into the frame; I find myself not needing to back up at all), to a strong zoom, which gets in plenty close.  I find the zoom range to be very impressive, considering the compact size of the camera, and this was one of the big selling points for me.  The 3" 460k LCD screen is really impressive- not just bright, but very sharp and exhibiting excellent contrast.  The only caveat here is that the screen seems to give the images a higher saturation than what you'll see on a monitor and prints.  720p HD movie mode is great, and while 1080P would of course be better, packing even 720P with a 12x optical zoom into such a small camera body is pretty impressive.  The GPS is also pretty cool, but I haven't really played around with it much.  The Intelligent Auto mode does most of thinking for you, automatically switching settings (and displaying the automatic settings on the screen for you), and generally taking excellent shots.  Manual controls are also available, allowing you to set up shots how you want, if preferred.  There is a large variety of Scene modes, with some of them proving very useful, as I'll talk about later.  Zoom speed is variable, which is nice.Cons:  I have three complaints when it comes to features.  First, while the proprietary battery makes sense in that it's much smaller than a pair of AA's, allowing the camera to be smaller, Panasonic makes it difficult to use anything but their own, high-priced batteries.  They claim it's to protect the camera from poor quality off-brand batteries, but the requirement sure doesn't hurt Panasonic's bottom line.  The Lumix Power Kit, sold through Amazon.com, does work with this camera, however, and for the price of 1 Panasonic battery, you get 2 batteries and a charger.  Next, you've got the proprietary USB connection.  Really, Panasonic?  The ONLY reason I can think of for a proprietary USB connection on a camera is to make more profit.  The proprietary USB slot is actually bigger than a micro-USB slot.  I have not been able to find any off-brand replacements for this cable.  Finally, while there is an HDMI port, which is very nice to have, the package doesn't include a mini-HDMI cable, so that must be purchased separately.Image Quality-Pros:  Relative to my past experiences (even including the Canon Rebel XS DSLR), the pictures taken from this camera are bright.  The camera seems to really make the best of the available lighting in a given area, and the result is clean, bright images.  As long as there is sufficient available lighting, the images don't exhibit any graininess or murkiness at all.  And yes, average indoor lighting is definitely sufficient for this camera.  There is a downside to this, however, which I'll mention later.  Images taken with sufficient lighting are crisp, but not noisy.  In Intelligent Auto (iA), I see sharp outlines between objects, but smooth skin.  There are some useful scene modes on this camera, including a very impressive Starry Night scene with selectable shutter speeds of 15, 30 or 60 seconds.  Simply mount the camera on a tripod in a dark room or outside at night, choose starry night, and the result is an impressively lit image with minimal noise- the images look almost surreal.  HDR mode gives you a couple of options, with the result of either a natural looking image with impressive shadow and highlight detail or an arty looking image with impressive shadow and highlight detail.Cons:  There are two negatives when it comes to image quality on this camera.  First, just like any point-and-shoot camera, high-ISO speeds breed noisy images.  If there isn't sufficient lighting, you can either have a dark picture (if you force ISO to max out at 400), or a noisy picture.  I wouldn't say that it's worse than other point-and-shoots, but it's amazing how much better a DSLR looks in low-lighting situations.  Second, this camera blows highlights with amazing consistency.  Maybe it's a side-effect of the bright, clean images, but I find that the brightest area of every picture I take is blown (i.e. pure white).  Even shooting in HDR mode, where the camera averages three different exposures in an effort to improve highlight and shadow detail, doesn't fix this problem.  Auto-bracketing helps (and it's nice that the camera has this feature), but I definitely think that the blown highlights are the biggest weakness of this camera.  Obviously, a DSLR camera does a better job with highlights, but then both of the Canon A-series cameras I have used also handle highlights better.  The trade-off is murkier pictures with the Canons.  I prefer the extra brightness, but you can only do so much in Photoshop with over-exposed areas.  I wouldn't call it a deal-breaker by any means, but just be advised that if you're seeking perfection, you should move along and look at DSLR's.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: A. Tilley "Signingmom"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because it claimed to have a larger lens than most point-and-shoots, quick burst picture taking (the time it takes to take a picture after you press the button) and manual override on aperture and f-stop and shutter speed.I have not been disappointed. The pictures are clear and beautiful.The things I love about it are:1. The way it lets you easily change the settings from portrait to scenery to action shots to many others2. The quick burst speed and the burst setting that allows you to take many, many pictures right in a row.3. The HD quality of the movies.4. The quick access menu, the flash, the timer are all there at the touch of one button.Things I don't love about it.1. The "digital camera photo" look of the pictures if you don't have the right setting. (It has a computerized look)2. The learning curve on all the extra features if you are not familiar with the extra settings. It does have an auto setting, but, as I said, the pictures are more computerized.All in all, I would recommend this camera to anyone looking for a high-quality camera that will still fit in your pocket. The pictures are not DSLR quality, but this is as close as I have seen for a point-and-shoot.

Reviews.Title: Well, finally now I can stop looking
Reviews.Author: G. H. Meraklis
Reviews.Content: For years I have been buying cameras, one after another.I always wanted an extended Zoom and not a SLR because they are big monsters and require big bag and lots and lots of parts and time to set everything up right to get a picture. So I wanted a good point and shoot.I had Sony's which takes great photos, and a good zoom,I had  Olympus's which has a tremendous zoom and good photos, and it little smaller.I had Kodak's that the photos were goods and it fit in my pockets but not the great zoom I wanted, and I had to carry around two cameras.I also had others that had good results but that was when a 3.2mp was the best you could get.Well they finally came out with "my dream camera" -that fit in your pockettakes great photos and is fast.and has a fantastic zoom.The steps I used was  to pick between two outstanding cameras, the Canon PowerShot SX210 IS or the Panasonic ZS7.  All others were ruled out because of bad reviews.I always wanted a canon but after reading some of the reviews of the frozen program malfunction where you have to shut down the camera to get it to work again I felt - "NO WAY HOSAY"  I had the same problem with the Kodak and I didn't want to go through with that again. It always happen when you have a great shot at something and you miss it because of the cameras having a frozen malfunction.Anyway I have the Panasonic ZS7 and couldn't be happier!  But that's me, we all have to do our own thing and make our own determination.But I really really Love my  Panasonic  ZS7

Reviews.Title: Superb camera
Reviews.Author: Myron R. Grover Jr.
Reviews.Content: Purchased camera about 1 month ago.  I carry it in my pocket most places I go.  Love that part.  I inadvertently dropped the camera on a cement curb.  Oh oh I thought now I have done it.  I picked the camera up and couldn't see any damage to the case.  The camera didn't like it and it malfunctioned for a bit.  After 5 minutes of rest, the camera was as good as new...whew!  I don't recommend this but my experience is great testimonial to the durability of the camera.  The quality of the photos are superb.  It has one of the most accurate automatic focus and  picture characteristic selection functions I have ever seen..  It is much better than a Canon point and shoot camera that I own.  As I expected the picture quality decreases in low lighting situations but is not bad.  The 16x optical zoom is a masterpiece.  It zooms both slowly and rapidly and makes only a soft click on playback.  It does a great job zooming during movie making however, it does take a moment to refocus as you zoom in low light situations.  It was one of the major reasons I purchased the camera and I am very pleased with the way it work.  I own a Mac and the  AVCHD lite movies don't load into iPhoto.  However, they do load into iMovie and can be viewed directly from camera to an HDTV.  The mpeg movies do load into iPhoto.  The quality of the HD movies  in both setting is excellent and surprisingly good in low light situations.  I do hope Apple will create a fix that will allow HVCHD lite movies to load directly into iPhoto. I leave the camera set on auto and the movies on jpeg settings and am as happy as a clam.I would give it a 7 star rating if I could.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Luminix DMC ZS3
Reviews.Author: bobdiver "Bob"
Reviews.Content: This is my 5th small size digital camera.  Love the compact size, excellent hi zoom 12X optical performance, the photo quality, the smile detection, the hi-def movie performance, and  the S/W.It does need a second battery as battery life is less than 300 pictures especially when using flash.Best picture quality of all my compacts and intermediate format digital cameras!

Reviews.Title: Shutter Lag Kills the Camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: After reading reviews, CNET I bought this camera primarily for taking point and shoot pictures of my 10 month old baby and everyday life. Anyone who has kids knows that you have a nano-second to capture the little smirk, twinkle in their eye, and those priceless two-tooth grins.  Sadly, this camera does not deliver.  I'm returning it within 24 hours of buying it.  (even though the lens and zoom are amazing!)Here's what I would have loved to know before buying it:1.  Shutter lag is very slow.  Painful!2.  Auto Focus is painfully slow.  It "thinks" a long time before actually focusing.3.  On the iA setting, the camera will only take about 2/3 of the pictures you try to snap.  If the camera doesn't like the image, it won't shoot.4.  You have to turn off the GPS setting every time you power up the camera; if you don't (others have said) it'll kill your battery. If you turn off GPS in one setting, it defaults to "on" when you turn it back on.5.  Menus are not intuitive; fairly complex to navigate.6.  If you primary reason for buying the camera is for point and shoot, this probably isn't the camera for you.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: E. Lacey
Reviews.Content: I have been looking for a small point-and-shoot camera for quite some time to complement my Canon 30D. After lots of research, I settled on the Lumix DMC-ZS7.  This is my first digital point-and-shoot camera.What I like about this camera...1. Really nice, compact size with a large, bright LCD screen.2. Love the GPS tagging3. High quality video4. Fairly easy to set up and simple menu options5. Very good photos outdoorsWhat I do not like about this camera...1. Poor quality indoor photos2. Cannot review photo without switching camera from "record" mode to "play" mode3. Weak flashMy motivation to purchase a point and shoot was primarily for indoor photos at parties, etc., where the light is generally not great.  I had 2 occasions to use this camera in these situations and it did not do a great job in either case.  I primarily used the camera in its iAuto mode, which I realize is often not the best mode to use for ANY digital camera.  However, I am really looking for a camera where it has a decent auto mode so I don't have to think about the photo and can just shoot.  The photos I was getting using iAuto were really poor.  LOTS of noise at most ISO levels, and basically unusable at ISOs above 400 when focus distance was over 10 feet or so.  When focal distance was under 10 feet, or when shooting in well lit situations, this camera did a good job.  I also shot in Program mode, whose only advantage was that I could define the upper end of the allowable ISO adjustment.  However, given that I was getting unacceptable noise starting at 400, and it was difficult to shoot indoors at under 400, I didn't get much better results in that mode.  I also shot in aperture and shutter priority modes, with mixed results.My other complaints with the camera are minor, and likely apply to just about all point-and-shoot cameras.  I don't like having the toggle the camera into a separate mode to review the photos that I have taken.  The flash has a rather limited reach-- under 10 feet I would guess.Ultimately, I have decided to return the camera.  The high noise photos in indoor situations is just not acceptable to me.  I will echo another reviewer here who stated that if you are a current digital SLR camera owner, then you probably will be disappointed with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Beware of easy Zoom errors
Reviews.Author: disappointed
Reviews.Content: The Panasonic Lumix DSC7 is what anyone can hope for in a digital camera. I had been a religious Canon camera user previously, but after being fed up with the limitations on the zoom (Canon 4x vs. Panasonic 12x), I decided to purchase a Panasonic Lumix. I am an avid backpacker, and wanted something that could really capture the beauty of the great outdoors, during the day and at night. In addition I wanted to have a camera that's really versatile, capturing birthday parties, evening dinners, concerts, etc.I have owned this camera for about 10 months. Within 5 months of owning this camera I began to encounter problems with the zoom. The camera gives a "System Error: Zoom" and shuts off. All of the smart features that people have reviewed are very compromised. Without a flash I can't hope to capture a crisp image after dusk. The zoom no longer works after a 5x range. My prints are pixelated.I have taken great care of this camera because I felt it was a great investment. Camera case, never dropped it. Perhaps this is why my greatest disappointment is not with the camera but with Panasonic Customer Service. I shipped in the camera, under warranty. They call me back saying they nullified my warranty because of "evidence of damage" --a nick on the corner of the camera and some wear on the lens ring. That's NORMAL wear of using a camera. I am losing my warranty because I used my camera? But don't worry, Panasonic is happy to give me a replacement refurbished unit for 200 dollars.I am sure you will love this camera if you choose to purchase it. Just beware that if anything goes wrong, I doubt Panasonic will help you recover your losses. A local repair shop will charge 150+ dollars. Those costs just don't make sense for point-and-shoots.And, just so you know, before this camera, I owned a Canon Powershot for 5+ years. I only upgraded because the technology was out of date. In fact, I have loaned it to a friend, and it is still working completely 100% intact.I'm afraid I am back on the camera market searching for something that is NOT a Panasonic.

Reviews.Title: Great pocketable superzoom for all occasions.
Reviews.Author: Thomas V Ives
Reviews.Content: I did a lot of research and pixel-peeping on review sites before I selected this camera, and it paid off.  I am traditionally a Canon fanboy, so it was hard for me to leave the bandwagon and sign on with a new brand, but I am now a Canon/Panasonic fanboy (with a hint of Pentax DSLR mixed in).  First off, the zoom lens is superb and produces clear shots from end to end, and with the i.zoom function you get 16x effective zoom capability.  The image stabilization is top-notch, making it possible to shoot still scenes in low light with low ISO, which makes it great for no-flash shots in museums and other indoor exhibitions.  Low light performance is excellent, and the dynamic range is great for a point-and-shoot portable (especially with the i.exposure setting turned on).  The macro function (AF macro) is very good and would be excellent for technical photography because there is very little distortion or softness in the images (but avoid the 'macro zoom function' - see cons below).  There is a built-in high-dynamic range (HDR) mode that works really nice and makes amazing B&W; photos if you are interested in artsy photography.  What really strikes me is the technical accuracy and clearness of the shots, which would make this camera excellent for scientific and technical work, and the GPS is a major bonus there.  Every good review has cons, so here are mine:  Cons - the menu system is different than Canon and it takes a little time getting used to the fact that the center button gets you *out* of a menu (it's not a select button).  The "macro zoom" function is disappointing b/c it uses digital zoom only, which isn't really apparent from the title, resulting in blocky pics if you use that particular zoom function.  I haven't tapped even 10% of the capacity of this camera yet, so the rest of the features that I haven't explored yet will just be icing on the cake.  The ZS7 is an amazing amount of camera in such a small package.  This camera is now my best small camera, easily beating my Canon S3is, A590, and A40 (old) - the Pentax K-x is technically better, but way too bulky to pop into a pocket for a trip to the zoo or museum.  And, for the Canon fans, bumping up the color saturation in-camera will result in very Canon-like images without having to post-process your shots.

Reviews.Title: Poor indoor picture qulity
Reviews.Author: Victor Gavrilenko
Reviews.Content: I owned this camera for about a month and still own its predecessor ZS3 for a year+. This camera takes amazing outdoor pictures when there is enough light. Indoor pictures are not as sharp and color balance is not always right. It is almost impossible to take a nice indoor picture of a group of people with flash or not. This is the main reason I will be returning this camera. Also in some cases camera gets confused which lighting mode to use for indoor shots (incandescent light or other), and takes pictures with over-saturated yellow/orange color.  The next picture of the same scene may get the right color mode.Another camera flaw comes from large lenses diameter, which results in longer circumference of lens mechanism and a greater chance of sand and dust getting into the camera through lenses. After one year of using similar camera ZS3 I can clearly see dust particles under lenses glass. If not careful with dust, camera can die after 1000-2000 pictures, Panasonic would send a replacement which will last another 1000-2000 pictures. It is important to carry this camera only in a case and never in a pocket/bag/purse even for short periods of time.

Reviews.Title: Great when not using my SLR. Panasonic is FABULOUS!
Reviews.Author: M. Taylor "mlt"
Reviews.Content: Why I bought it:I use an SLR usually. I bought this camera for a few reasons1. I wanted something that I could also buy an underwater case for, for under water photography2. I wanted something smaller for taking places that you might not want to reveal the fact that you have an expensive camera with you.3. I wanted something light, small and something I would not worry about as much as my SLR for extreme hiking in rather rugged and/or wet conditions... Amazon rain forest, Alakai, canyoneering, etc. (In this scenario I  kept the camera in its waterproof case that I bought)Pros:1. The response time is fast for a point and shoot (not like my SLR but much better then the point and shoots my friends own that I have tried out).2. The lens is impressive! Very good range of zoom levels effectively (25mm - 300mm)3. The dynamic range is respectable for a point and shoot.4. Worked alright in dark situations. Better then what I expected from a point and shoot.5. Has a descent set of manual features.6. The screen died. Why did I list this as a "pro" and not a "con"? Because It was under the 1 year Panasonic warranty and from the day I dropped the camera off at the post office until the day I got it back at my door was 9 days. (And I live on one of the smaller islands of Hawaii so shipping is not trivial). The process was not hard at all and I think they have great customer service. I plan to stick with Panasonic if I ever go to another point and shoot in the future!Cons:1. The camera did a couple of odd things when I tried to do a 60 second exposure of stars (Note: this is something that I in all seriousness would only use my SLR for but I thought I would try it out). The picture failed to save it self to the card. Perhaps this is a problem with the card? Anyhow, I will leave this kind of photo work to my SLR.Margot

Reviews.Title: The Hesitant Fan
Reviews.Author: billyburg_gal
Reviews.Content: I must admit that when I first received my camera, and tried it out, I wasn't too sure about it. I had previously been a long time Canon user, and loved my old camera...which alas had died. I love taking photos (mostly during vacations) but in no way would I consider myself knowledgeable on the ins and outs of photography. I'm pretty much a point and shoot kind of gal. After a few days of taking lots of pictures and still being unsure as to whether or not I was going to keep it, I decided to print the manual and get serious about learning how to use all of the features this camera had to offer. I even ordered a photography book off of Amazon. I then went and purchased a Canon SX20 IS too, so I could compare the 2 cameras. After a few weeks of playing with my Panasonic, I have come to love it...and today my Canon SX20 IS went back to the store. Even my husband, who was a big proponent for the Canon, had to admit that the shots I took with the Panasonic were better than the Canon. I think anyone that buys a new camera should give it at least a few weeks to get a feel for it before deciding to send it back. I'm so glad I decided to experiment with mine and keep it. While no camera is perfect, for me, this one comes close. btw...I have no opinion on the GPS because I haven't even tried to use it. I don't really care about that feature...at least for now. I am now a Panasonic convert!

Reviews.Title: Awsome Camera, Bang for the Buck!
Reviews.Author: Whoseyurdaddy
Reviews.Content: Read the reviews of many point & shoot digitals and decided to get my 13 yr son this one before we left on a 3 state, in 6 days, vacation.  Well, 600 pictures later and many uploads to facebook, make this a must have all around great family/vacation/travel light camera.  This camera will out perform nearly all other compact point and shoot cameras in it's class for these reasons. It has a larger diameter lens aperature, fast shutter and zoom speed, which makes there virtually no lag in focus find and image capture, and takes great videos.  What it lacks is what all small diameter lens cameras lack.  Poor results in far range low level light situations, but this is reality and just the nature of the beast. I recommend you get the 16 gig SD memory card and at least 1 or more extra batteries.  It gets about 65 to 85 shots on the pansonic battery supplied with the camera, and I bought 2 batteries for $28.00 and they get only about 40 to 70 pics before they scream for a re-charge.  This is totally reasonable and as a professional photographer, I enjoyed giving this camera a test drive, while passing on secrets of my passion for the last 35 years to my son.  Hope this review was helpful.  Jesse

Reviews.Title: What an Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: LC Webb "lc webb"
Reviews.Content: I read a lot of reviews before I decided to purchase this camera. Some of the negative views almost stoped me from buying. Since having it, I have utterly enjoyed it. I made what I thought was a making feeble attempt and making a video until I put it on my computer, WOW! I felt like a movie maker without trying to hard. Only thing missing as far as I can tell is not being able to remove redeye.

Reviews.Title: Too many problems
Reviews.Author: Dadbee
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera after reading all the positive reviews. I was replacing a 5 year old Canon SD550 which I really liked, but broke after a fall. I returned this camera for the following reasons:- Battery life is so-so. I purchased 2 batteries, but who wants to worry about multiple batteries on a vacation day with the family? If you buy this camera, you will need an additional battery or you will be bummed out when the kids want their picture with Mickey Mouse and you're out of juice.- Image quality of people not what I wanted. I realize this is personal preference, but I much prefer the skin tones and vibrancy rendered by my older canon point and shoot. This in itself was a dealbreaker for me. Photos of people just too grayish and cold. Fine for landscapes but not for photos of family and friends.- No fill-in flash in automatic mode. I has to switch to Program mode just to enable the flash for fill in. I use this often, so it's kind of a pain.- Blown out highlights. Noticeable.- This camera is quite bulky compared to my old Canon.- While the move quality is fantastic, the avchd format is a pain. Most software does not support it, so I had to figure out workarounds. Conversions to MPG using the Panasonic software were not great.In all - too many problems. I didn't want to spend the next few years with this camera.Positives?  GPS is cool. Zoom is great. Movie quality is awesome.

Reviews.Title: Excellent GPS and iA (intelligent Automatic) modes
Reviews.Author: Kenneth R. Niebling "niebling"
Reviews.Content: I happily received the camera today from Amazon along with two batteries purchased from eForceCity Panasonic DMW-BCG10 Decoded Replacement Battery for Panasonic LUMIX DMC-ZR1 / DMC-ZS1 / DMC-ZS3 / TZ6 / TZ7 Digital Camera and a mini HDMI to HDMI cable from Monoprice.First - Reviews claiming that the Panasonic DMW-BCG10PP battery is the only type that will work are inaccurate. PN-DMW-BCG10E 'DECODED' battery 3.7V 1000mAh works great. With firmware version 1.1 . The battery will set you back 7 skins if you shop around.Second - The build of this camera is SUPER excellent and buttons are well placed.  The first thing I did was to power up, set the camera to iA (intelligent Automatic mode) and shoot a picture of my coffee cup at 10 megapixel 16x9 format.  Depressing the shutter halfway performed a stable autofocus and the flash went off giving a great detailed picture. The camera only has 15MB of built-in memory and this is only enough to hold 3 pictures at this resolution. (you need an SDHD card for this camera, suggest SanDisk Class 6 8GB Sandisk 8GB EXTREME SDHC HD Video Card Class 6 - 20MB/s (SDSDRX3-8192) [Hassle-Free Packaging], 16GB or Patriot Class 10 16 GB Patriot LX Series 16 GB Class 10 SDHC Flash Memory Card PSF16GSDHC10 (Black)Third - Install the software (see below for possible bugs in the installation) - Add directories for scanning to PhotoFun Studio application (this application searches subfolders and identifies many picture files that you might not be aware of that are on your computer!!!)Pros: - Durable build, large 240,000 pixel screen, 12x zoom, leica lens, 720p HD video (purchase a high quality SDHD card - at least Class 6), AVC HD video using x264 video codec, easy navigation, quick menu access to  delete photo, 12MP resolution (14MP CCD chip), 4:3 or 16:9 formats, image stabilization (good for telephoto shots and set as default for video recording), GPS, detailed manual with tips for shooting best pictures.Neutral: - Quicktime motion JPEG video format for lower quality vids - 720p HD video (Nikon or Canon might provide higher res for video)Cons: - Limited availability of "freeware" AVC HD conversion software (not fault of product) (more later...) - Sleep mode disables camera output and requires power off and then power on to restore camera output (pushing the menu button does not activate the camera... no big deal)Software: - Software installation was easy enough, but for the Photo Application the setup required that I identify the location of the 'Microsoft 2008 Redistributable C++ library' installer which was transiently copied to the root of my C: drive by the launcher.exe application under some cryptic directory (7CafHJ35teYuGEHH00FFa just as an example...). Solution: 1) Just search for the necessary .msi file using Windows Search  2) navigate to the directory containing the asked for .msi file  hint: right mouse click ('open file location'),  3) select the file with the mouse and hit 'OK'.  4) Reboot your computer after installation is finished and update the software via the PhotoFun Studio application under the 'Help' menu. - Quicktime is also installed as an option for viewing motion JPEG files. AVC HD videos can also be viewed in the included PhotoFun Studio application. (the extension of the HD AVC videos is either mt2s or mts (will specify when I have shot some videos). Installation of Quicktime is better done by acquiring the latest version and installing manually.  Quicktime Pro (not free) allows editing and creation of videos.  I had to navigate to the installer on the Panasonic software disk because the launcher did not enable the installation of the Quicktime software for me.  In addition, the Quicktime software may be installed on top of a previous version of Quicktime that you have on your computer. This may be an issue for you.Provided Cables: - The camera comes with a proprietary USB cable for connecting the camera to your computer.  After plugging in the camera via this cable the device driver is immediately installed by Windows 7x64 bit OS. The camera also comes with a Component A/V cable for connection to devices supporting component type connections such as HDTV and flat screen monitors although connection via a mini HDMI to HDMI cable is preferred (see below).Optional Cable: - I also purchased a mini HDMI to HDMI cable for connection to my 1080p monitor/HDTV for about 6 clams - or mini HDMI to HDMI adaptor sold thru Amazon RiteAV - HDMI to Mini HDMI Type C Adapter - 8 inch (this is really not optional - increases quality of viewing on 1080p monitors for minimal cost)Connectivity and resulting image rendering: - Viewing images on my LG1080p HDTV/monitor (see 'Equipment List' below) was a total pleasure... Best: Image rendering was best by connecting to my HDTV with the optional mini HDMI to HDMI cable via a direct connection to my HDTV/monitor configured for 1080p 16:9 format. Excellent: Detail was rendered at HD 1080p resolution (upscaled by my Seagate Theatre+ media player to 1080p) 16:9 format and gave greater resolution than my laptop monitor [I could easily read the calories on a  can or 'Bumble Bee Tuna' from a picture taken in iA (intelligent Automatic mode) from 6ft @ 200iso 1/15th of a second exposure with flash] Very Good: Detail was very good when viewed on my laptop 1366x768 screen resolution (Intel Graphics, onboard vanilla flavor)  using IrfanView graphics application. (you can probably expect similiar results or better using other software and good video graphics hardware. Very Good: Detail was very good when connecting via VGA from laptop to VGA port on LG 1080p monitor configured for 1920x1080 resolution (Intel Graphics, onboard vanilla flavor)  ???:  Could not test. HDMI connection to HDTV/Monitor via HDMI [ my laptop does not have HDMI output :( ]  I suspect that the rendering of these images could be awesome. Good: Detail was good using my Seagate Theatre + Media Player set for 720p resolution (no upscaling...) Seagate FreeAgent Theater+1080P HD Media Player STCEA201-RK Acceptable: Detail was rendered good, but noticeably degraded by direct connection to my 1080p HDTV/monitor using the included HDMI to Component cable provided with the camera. (Not recommended for HD) Equipment list: Lumix SZ7 camera, Seagate Theatre+ Media Player (upscaling to 1080p), LG 22" HDTV/1080p LCD Monitor or 32" equivalent thru Amazon: LG 32LD450 32-Inch 1080p 60Hz LCD HDTV, Lenovo laptop 1366x768 resolution 15.6" monitor w/Intel onboard graphics, mini HDMI to HDMI cable (see above under optional cable) or RiteAV - HDMI to Mini HDMI Type C Adapter - 8 inch, Component A/V cable (provided w/ camera), USB/PC cable (provided w/camera), Image Viewer Software (optional) I recommend IrfanView package [freeware, many good plugins, highly configureable, Exif aware, IPTC aware, GPS mapping via GoogleEarth, GeoHack-Wiki (access to many GPS mapping tools)]GPS: - GPS connectivity is set as off by default (saves on battery).  GPS of sample image pegged my address when viewed on Google Maps, Bing Maps, or GeoHack-Wiki.  The IrfanView software (freeware) is great for viewing EXIF data attached to JPEG images by the camera and can map the coordinates of the GPS information in GoogleEarth, and GeoHack-Wiki (access to GoogleEarth, Bing Maps and other GPS aware mapping tools).  The Lumix SZ7 pegged the image to my address but about 100 ft from the exact location. See my example images under 'Customer Images' user="niebling"Notes: I will update this review next week after heavy testing of this camera.Recommend: Gordon's video review at Cameralabs.com (excellent video review for this camera and Nikon/Canon competitor models)

Reviews.Title: The Ultimate Camera
Reviews.Author: Stanley L.
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for a gift for my brother who has been an amateur photographer for over 50 years and who has spent tons of money on larger bulky cameras and attachments and after using it once he was AMAZED at the quality of the images and ease of operation in such a small camera with no needed lens attachments and having to set up every picture before shooting it.  It has the brain of Einstein.  When I saw the results and used the camera myself (never enjoyed picture taking) I rushed onto Amazon.com to order one in red for myself.  When the photos it takes were shown to friends and family they too were amazed and consequently had to buy one for themselves.  4 more cameras were purchasrd just by seeing the one my brother was given as a gift.  The secret to such quality photos must be in the Leica lens and the Auto Intelligence mode in this Panasonic Lumix camera!

Reviews.Title: I cannot think of a feature I'd want that this doesn't have
Reviews.Author: John Huesman "QPhysics"
Reviews.Content: Once my wife and I decided we wanted a new digital camera that would also take HD video, I spent (literally) weeks going over reviews, buyer's guides, manufacturer's web sites, and going to retail stores to see the cameras. No matter how I analyzed the results, only one camera kept coming out in the top 3 choices, and was number 1 in most categories: the Lumix ZS7. So we bought it and I couldn't be happier about that decision.What sets this camera apart from the others is the lens. I've posted some pictures that I took right after opening the box; it's hard to tell the difference between the picture of a (fake) flower taken from 4 inches and a picture of the same flower taken from across the room at full optical zoom. And the picture of the text on a printed paper was taken with the lens body actually sitting on the paper! If you need a camera that will take a closer picture with sharper, crisper details...I don't think you could find one at any price.Besides the iA setting, which is suitable for almost any purpose, there are a couple dozen specialty scene settings. The one I use most often is the panorama assist; take the first picture, and the camera shows you part of that image only moved to the opposite side of the screen...line that up now, and you're ready for shot number 2...repeat until you've taken the full angle panorama you want. This is soooooo much nicer than the "I'll try to make sure I have a good object for reference and hope the computer software can do it" approach I had to do with my older camera (I cannot tell you how much I wish I'd had this when I was in Italy doing panoramas in Pisa, Rome, and Florence). And if none of those are what you need, you can define your own settings on the exposure, f-stop, etc. and save them as a macro.The video is amazing. Any of the HD settings will take good video, so it's really up to the user to decide what matters more, higher resolution but less shooting time or lower (but still HD) resolution and more movie before you have to switch SD cards. I hook the camera up directly to my 1080p TV to watch the videos and they are truly incredible. I don't see any motion blur or pixelation, even in low light shooting (my daughter and I on a carousel at the county fair, for example).Photo lag is practically nonexistent (and it has a burst mode if you really need several pictures taken per second). I was taking pictures at an ocean-based attraction park in Orlando (I'm not sure if I can use trademarked names here, but you know where I mean) and I have pictures, not in burst mode, of a dolphin jumping out of the water, the dolphin at the top of its jump, the dolphin about half-way back into the water, and the splash...so four pictures in a little over a second.I don't use the GPS functionality often, but I have taken a couple pictures while hiking that were just too stunning a view not to be able to find it again, so turn on the GPS, imprint the location onto the photo, then turn the GPS back off to save the battery (it does seem to be quite the battery hog).The only less-than-perfect mark I can give this camera is that it uses a special battery instead of cheap, rechargeable AA's like my previous camera. But you can buy backup batteries either made by Panasonic (not cheap, or course) or 3rd-party like the ones in the kit I bought TheZipKit for PANASONIC BCG-10. Includes: 2 BCG-10 1200mAh Ultra High Capacity Batteries made with cells produced in JAPAN or USA, Table-Top Wire Tripod, 110/240 Mini Charger with fold out plug and a DC car adapter, SD/SDHC Card Reader, LCD Protection F...The LCD view screen is large, can show lots of information or get everything out of your way depending on the settings you choose. I like how it reads your SD card, computes, and shows you right on the LCD how many pictures or how many minutes of video you still have room for!The lens is so good I'm actually quite surprised to find it on a camera at this price.The camera has pretty much every function you'll ever need or want.Uses SD, SDHC, and SDXC cards, so you'll never run out of memory. (I have a 16GB SDHC card in mine and have never come close to filling it...that will hold a couple hundred pictures PLUS nearly 2 hours of video on the lower HD setting and still not be full! But I carry an 8GB card in the case just in case.)Even with the silly battery thing (I'd hate to not have the couple backups I bought because if your battery dies, you're out of luck for an hour at least, and that's if you have your charger with you and can find a place to plug it in...I really prefer AA batteries in portable devices) this camera gets a strong 5 out of 5. (I would give it 97 out of 100 if we could be that precise on Amazon ratings.)

Reviews.Title: Great as long as you're outdoors
Reviews.Author: Kelly from GA "kellybethga"
Reviews.Content: I just purchased a sidekick camera to my olympus e-pl1 and tested the zs7.  I sold my tz5 on ebay not long ago, and would describe it as the most aggravating, frustrating camera EVER to use in low light. If you're a parent preparing to take lots of kid photos, which happens a lot at birthday parties and such, please make sure to try this camera out to make sure it fits your tastes before buying.  The zs7 is better than the tz5.  However, if you like to use full-auto mode, the camera prefers to choose indoor portrait mode, which ups the ISO and uses flash, and if the subject is more than, say, 3 feet away, you'll get day-glo kids.  Using P mode and choosing WB doesn't help much.  Even in its best pictures, it chose to make blue eyes greensish.The zs7 does have its good points - it takes great movies and its pictures are very sharp (unless you go up in ISO).  It's responsive and has a 12x zoom, way out from a high angle.  If you primarily shoot anything but people, this is a nice camera.

Reviews.Title: Exceptional Point and Shoot, but the JPEG Compression is too high
Reviews.Author: Paul Tinsley "Tinz"
Reviews.Content: I really wish they had provided the ability to tweak the JPEG Compression for this camera. Most of the features are flawless and it takes very decent pictures in strong lighting conditions. Of course, the images look awful close up, but the resolution is high enough to get large prints with considerable clarity. This camera would be unbeatable if they had provided a way to tweak the JPEG Compression. I can see that it compresses just a little too much, and I reckon that with the very large SDHC Cards around now, most users wouldn't mind larger files. I think they just evaluated the best trade-off between the most likely print size and the minimum file size necessary to deliver a decent image.The GPS is a great feature, but it is very unreliable. My wife drove to Denver and had the camera with the GPS mode on all of the time, even when the camera is off, and despite spending most of the day in Denver, the camera recorded a GPS location for our home for every photograph. The camera had been exposed to the sky for most of the day, so I have no idea why this happened and it's a bit of a letdown. When the GPS does work, its a great feature.Overall, we are very happy with this camera serving as a handy point-and-shoot. It doesn't replace our DSLR by any stretch, but it works out at a fairly good value for the price. The video is the best that I have seen for a camera of its size and has excellent motion stability, even at maximum zoom. The zoom is also phenomenal for the size of the camera and the wide angle sucks in vastly more picture than any other point-and-shoot that I have had before.I deducted 1 point for the GPS instability and the lack of more JPEG compression settings. Other than that, it's an amazing camera that will rarely let you down.Update 31st July, 2010:I have taken a lot of shots now in "P" mode with Sharpness at -1 and Noise Reduction at -2. This has greatly improved the image clarity, so I would now rate this camera at 4.5, losing only half a point for some GPS instability. There was a firmware update recently, and this seems to have made GPS better, but I can't be certain until I have tested a few other areas. If fixed, this camera is a definite 5 star buy!

Reviews.Title: F30 vs TZ10 - it's not all about the ISO
Reviews.Author: S. J. Bennett
Reviews.Content: After reading enough camera reviews to make me go blind I jumped in and bought the Panasonnic TZ10. I already own the very excellent Fuji F30, and I wanted a camera that took equally good photos, as well as good quality HD video. Our 6 month old daughter is growing up just too fast, and I didn't want to film another minute of her at 640x480.Well it was all too obvious as soon as I started filming that this is one excellent camera for HD video. Good image quality, great image stabilisation, powerful zoom, and very good sound. The only video drawback is in low light, but it's probably just as good as an equally priced video camera (my assumption). It's also great having the option to use either AVCHD or Motion JPEG - AVCHD does have better sound though, and it practically doubles the recording time with no visible loss in video quality.The next challenge for me was to compare the photo quality with the F30, and after various un-scientific tests (I'm not a pro) I can safely conclude that they are very very similar. I mean the cameras themselves are very different, but the results are practically the same. My biggest fear was that the TZ10 wouldn't keep up with the F30 in low light, because this is where the F30 is well known for it's great performance.The fact is that the F30 actually does outperform the TZ10 in this category, HOWEVER the TZ10 makes up for lost ground with it's image stabilisation. Example: With no flash, the F30 took a great portrait of my wife in low light, with an ISO of 800 and a shutter speed of 1/60th of a second (any less than 1/50th is too blurry due to camera shake). The TZ10 took an equally good photo using ISO400 and a shutter speed of (get this) 1/6th of a second! And not the slightest bit blurry! Both photos were somewhat noisy at full zoom, but at regular 19" screen-size both photos looked great, and almost identical to the eye.So all in all a great result. I have a new camera that rivals the F30 in photo quality, has the benefit of HD video, and for me a few other bonus benefits: Great long zoom, crystal clear hi-res screen, longer recording time on an SDHC or SDXC card (8gb = 1 hour)One last thing - I have to make mention of the Intelligent Auto mode, because it's just so great. I think trying to make a better shot using manual controls would be like trying to beat a computer at chess. It's almost never wrong so I just leave it on iA all the time. That is unless I'm photographing my baby, in which case I use the Baby scene mode. I can highly recommend this very good camera.

Reviews.Title: Best Compact Camera I have owned..
Reviews.Author: S. HUBERT
Reviews.Content: I am thinking of selling my Canon dSLR because this little camera takes such awesome shots...Here is what I LOVE about this camera:- 720p recording with stereo sound- Insane 14x zoom- GPS tagging shows on a map in my iPhoto where the photo was taken- Durable weight and feel, I feel like I am holding something strong and solid in my hand- Amazing outdoor photo qualityHere is what I DON'T LOVE (But can live with) about this camera:- GPS is slow to acquire position, so if you whip it out for a quick shot it won't have time to find out where you are- Indoor flash photography isn't amazing. Average for a camera in this price point but could be better.Overall if you do most of your photo taking outside this will be a dream camera for you. If you travel and want to remember the places you visited on a map. This is the dream camera for you.I couldn't recommend this camera enough.

Reviews.Title: lumix camera is great!
Reviews.Author: Diane D. Browne
Reviews.Content: I LOVE my new camera--such clear pictures and the intelligent auto is great for someone like me.  Even low light has been wonderful--truly a great buy for the price!  Get the extra battery and it doesn't come with a memory card so you need that too. Nice and small also so you can take it everywhere without a problem.  Yeah!!!

Reviews.Title: LOVE this little camera.and gives it 5 stars.
Reviews.Author: Mr. Richard J. Harper Jr.
Reviews.Content: I just got this little camera and Love it.  It replaced my FX-100S and what I love about it is that 16-1 Power Zoom,  so clear and crispy plus the most important is the Zoom while using the video part while the others don't have this option.  I also ordered a Travel Kit from Unigue's with TWO spare battery's and travel charger, cases, film screen protectors for only $29.  The battery's are the Correct ones with the electronic memory for that camera.  Best camera yet for me and I have had LOT'S of camera'a.......

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Martin Batten
Reviews.Content: I received this camera a couple of days before my son's graduation. I took it with me and:1) Was impressed with the zoom.  It did as well a SLR being operated be a guy in the seat in front of me.  And it slid in my pocket as needed.  Needless to say; not so for his SLR.2) Solid construction. It feels robust.  Metal body, no flexing parts.  Buttons are quite usuable, one dedicated for movie taking makes access to that feature easy. Powser switch is a slider - sensible and functional - reduces the likelehood of being pressed accidentally.3) Doubles as a video camera. As the light faded into the evening it proved to make quality movies even in poor light.  And captured the sounds quite well.4) Picture quality was noticably superior to the Nikon compact I was previously using.  And image stabilization helps in low light.  Similar to my Sony Alpha SLR in picture quality.  This is a marked step up for a compact.5)Three hours of intermittent assorted movie and photo taking did not even reduce the battery bar count by one.It was a great success in recording my son's event.It uses a large CCD (1/2.3") and is more feature-rich than I will likely ever delve into.It comes with a compact charger wal-wart for the battery that is a nice feature.I had to use the software application that came with it to watch the videos, but have not done much research yet with AVCHD Lite.The GPS does not work indoors, I have not played with it yet; did not see it as a critical feature.  Very small antenna.Overall my first impression is this is one sweet camera.  There are plenty of models out there, this stands high in the list of products in the mid-300s.  I would recommend it to a friend. Or You!

Reviews.Title: High quality (for the price) in a small package.
Reviews.Author: T. Lakiotis "Light wizzard"
Reviews.Content: I am used to high Quality DLSR and I needed a light-weight camera to be used in small and crowded areas (like Museums or churches) where it'd be difficult to switch from Wide to Tele lenses and vise versa. I visited a couple museums in the DC area a month ago and was very satisfied with the photos the camera produced. Good color accuracy and easy to operate (maybe I am used to more complicated DLRS). Very dissapointed on the quality of the software - again, maybe because I am used to more sophisticated ones. That said, Panasonic could have used an easier to use software package with a few more tools to compliment a very good camera. You'll pay a bit more for a colored body, so if money is not an object, go splurge. Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 12.1 MP Digital Camera with 12x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black)

Reviews.Title: Very nice camera but beware image quality
Reviews.Author: Steven Brys "Koala Lover!"
Reviews.Content: I own way too many cameras as I love to try them out to see if a particular one is "it" - the perfect small camera.  There are a lot of nice things about the ZS7.  Like many have mentioned, it sports a terrific range in a small form factor (25-300mm).  It offers complete manual, automatic, or anywhere in between shooting options.  There are a host of nice scene modes that are fun to experiment with ranging from common ones like beach, snow, candlelight to more artistic ones such as dynamic range and pinhole photography.  Just about every bell and whistle on the market, are on this camera and then some.For me, however, the bottom line is image quality.  Now you must have realistic expectations.  After all, this is a small point and shoot camera with a small sensor and there is no way it is a substitute for a dslr, or a micro 4/3 camera.  The trade off is you don't have to change (or pay for) expensive lenses, the camera is tiny and can go everywhere.  Basically your investment of time or money ends at the purchase price.  But I gave this camera 3 stars because I felt even within the peer group, the image quality is noticeably poor.  Noise is evident even at the lowest ISO setting of 80.  Because of this, the noise reduction within the camera is heavy and the details get smeared and hence, lost.  You can lower the noise reduction setting but you cannot shut it off.  And shooting Raw is not supported, so there is a limited ability to even work around this issue.Now, many people will not notice or care.  If you are looking for a snap shooter, convenient, latest technology, and that long zoom range this camera deserves serious consideration. But for me the poor image quality overwhelms the many positive aspects of this camera.

Reviews.Title: PHENOMENAL HD QUALITY VIDEO;COOL FILTERS;63.8x ZOOM!!(YES-THAT'S RIGHT)
Reviews.Author: C. Caldwell "LuvAlltech"
Reviews.Content: I just bought the Panasonic Lumix DMC ZS7 4 days ago, and I've been nothing but pleased and amazed with it.  I had read the reviews and watched multiple videos, and was frankly sold on getting the Fujifilm FinePix HS10, with it's 30X optical zoom and 1080p HD recording.  I hadn't considered anything else.  But I clicked on a banner ad for the DMC ZS7, liked what I saw, and researched further.  I ultimately chose it over the FujiFilm HS10, and don't regret it.Let's start with the DMC ZS7 zoom....it says right on the camera when you open the box "16X Intelligent Zoom".  That's  a combined 12X optical with a 4X digital.  The 30X optical zoom  was what drew me initially to the FujiFilm HS10.  But guess what I discovered about the Lumix DMC ZS7??  Something that many reviews, both professional and amateur, seemed to have missed??  The DMC ZS7 is capable of an astounding 63.8X extended zoom!!!  I discovered it in the vast array of submenus that are present on the camera.  The firmware is lightning fast, and navigating menus is quick and effortless, and the 4-directional keypad works well and feels solid under your fingers as you use it.  The camera is part plastic, part metal, and is heavy for a point and shoot, and I like that "not cheap" feeling.  But about the zoom.It's 12X optical plus 4X digital...so it says on the camera itself...and so many others have said...but after going through the array of submenus in the setup options, I found where you can turn on and extened digital zoom, an EXTRA 51.8X!!!  No lie.  Of course, it's grainy at best, and pixelized, but pics come out surprisingly well, and video, at the max range, are not as diluted as one might think.  For best quality, stick with 16X--that's covered by Panasonic's proprietary "Intelligent Resolution", which keeps things hella-sharp.  After that, yes, the pic and video quality degrade.  But still, the max 63.8X zoom is bearable, and is helpful in situations where you just have to get up close.  More expensive bridge megazoom cameras also get blurry and have focus issues as you max out the zoom.  I know, I have an Olympus SP 570UZ bridge camera that does that.  I can deal with it on a pocketable point and shoot!I just uploaded a wealth of videos on YouTube displaying the zoom capabilities of the DMC ZS7; I don't have the link as I'm writing this.  I'm going to try and upload some videos right here after I finish this review, and maybe find that link to the YouTube vids I posted.DO GET A FAST, SANDISK, CLASS 10  20 OR 30 Mbps SDHC card!!  It's what allows me to take video (by merely pressing one red dedicated "record" button) in 720p and brilliant, "punchy", 12 megapixel stills, with little to no delay between shots and recordings.  Anything less would be...uncivilized...LOL.  Seriously,  Amazon has great cards at reasonable prices, and I purchased an 8GB SanDisk Class10  30Mbps read/write Extreme card, and the choice is rewarding.  No long waits between shots & recording, no BS.I like the menus and indicators on the screen when you film.  As you zoom, the actual number zoomX is printed on the screen and increases as you go all the way to 63.8X(extended zoom "on").  Not just a zoom bar.  An icon shows what scene mode you're in, or what filter you're using  (I like the "Film Grain" black and white setting, which adds an Old World style class and charm to your stills AND  videos--yes, it works on videos, and the PinHole setting which makes you look through a virtual "pinhole" for that "peeping" effect) .  When you record, the square reticule flashes red,  a red dot above flashes, and there is an icon flashing with an arrow pointing to a memory card.  You definitely know you're recording!  No wondering.  Stills same thing, just green.  Every function you enact is clearly and visually displayed,  nothing cryptic.  Easy and bold and defined.  Always know EXACTLY your function, filter, etc.  Counts down recording seconds on screen, and time left on the card in seconds and minutes right on the screen.  There's TWO PAGES of scene modes and filters.  Multiple options for GPS (yes, there's a "bump" on the camera top that proudly displays the GPS logo).  If you're into geo-tagging your filming and using them in iPhoto on Mac, it's my understanding it works great with "Faces".  I have an Apple iMac 24" with iPhoto '09, but I haven't tried the GPS feature on the DMC ZS7 yet.  It's well documented that it SEVERELY drains the included lithium battery (Amazon offers the exact replacement  at a good price---get the original with the "PP" designation or it won't fit).Quick note about importing to a Mac---When I tried to import my 1st  stills and vids, my 8GB Sandisk Class10 Extreme card did not import everything-even on multiple tries.  However, my Windows 7 HP laptop had NO problems EASILY importing ALL the content.  Can't explain that yet.  Not the card, otherwise why did it work on my Windows 7 laptop?The 720p HD recordings on the DMC ZS7 are OUTSTANDING.  I've seen test videos of the 1080p vids on the Fujifilm HS10 that can't hold a candle to what I get with the Lumix.  Panasonic's algorithms for resolution and clarity REALLY are a tour-de-force to be reckoned with, and ACTUALLY  WORK!!  Zooming is smooth and fast (slower on vids, I admit, but still good).  You have a "zoom resume" feature that allows you to cut the camera on from sleep mode, and start shooting with the exact zoom level you left off at.  The sound is recorded from 2 mics set on the camera's top, and provide sterling audio.  In options you can cut off the "wind effect"  so that the sensitive mics don't pick up wind noises that might obliterate the more important audio in your recordings.  You can control the LCD display brightness to 3 levels, and it is 460,000 pixels, not the standard 240,000, as the card attached to the camera says when you get it.  That's evident when you play back your HD movies.  I zoomed in on a float gliding across the pool,  and you can actually see the "Inflate instructions" and safety precautions printed on it.The exposure, one-touch recording button, and switch for playback and filming are located in the upper right corner on the back,  and CAN be hit accidentally.  I find  myself consciously always trying to avoid that, though I've never had any "accidental" recordings or stills taken.  But it is the only little nitpick I can think of on an otherwise "Joy-to-use",  "easy-to-understand",  PHENOMENAL  point & shoot  that is a pocketable, portable powerhouse.  Like a mini-DSLR in your pocket.  AMAZING performance (get the FAST card...).  Oh! Just thought of another nitpick.  There's  vertical light streaks present when you film DIRECTLY into a light source, such as the sun, oncoming nighttime headlights, etc.  But the lowlight capabilities on the DMC ZS7 are INCREDIBLE--zooming with little to no blur, and excellent clarity.  Okay, this has become a  Bible, and I've only had the camera 4 days.  I'll update when I discover anything new or significant.  These are my 1st impressions, and don't cover every technical aspect, so sorry.  Just wanted to convey the pleasure of owning and using what has now replaced my more expensive Megazoom as my camera of choice---"What's the best Camera?  The one you have with you..."I forgot only one review can be submitted for a product here, but I wanted you to see how to achieve the 63.8X zoom for this Lumix, so go to YouTube and type this into the SEARCH bar:  PANASONIC DMC-ZS7 INSTRUCTIONS ON HOW TO GET 63.8X ZOOM  Take you straight to my video & others as well. Enjoy.UPDATE Sept.8th 2010: It was my fault that my Sandisk 8GB Class10 Extreme card was not importing videos to my iMac.  In the "Record Mode" options, you have the choice of "AVCHD Lite GPS", "AVCHD Lite", or "Motion JPEG". I had the ZS7 set to "AVCHD Lite", which is not compatible with the iMac. When you try to import, you get executable files in the window & and it says the "file format is not compatible".  I'm assuming "AVCHD Lite GPS" would be no different, just with geo-tagging. So I tried "Motion JPEG". Took some test vids. Imported with no problems. It's interesting to note that not only are the videos imported, but also an iconic pic that represents the 1st frame of each video that is taken. The "Motion JPEG" setting allows for WVGA, QVGA, VGA, and HD.  I chose HD, which also shows up as a movie icon with the HD letters stamped on it when you're filming, so you know what record mode you're in, as well as the quality chosen.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Grover C. Sharp
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my wife after she took a trip to Las  Vegas. My daughter took all the pictures because my wife just could not use the 35mm I gave her to take. There was no learning curve at all with the Panasonic, now she is not intimidated at all taking pictures. Have not used it yet for video, but I think it takes great photos. I have since researched all the P&S; i could find trying to justify buying one for myself. At the end I decided I wasn't going to find a better one. Everyone talks highly of the Canon S95. I'm sure its a good camera, I own a decent Canon S2I, the technology is ancient but it still takes very good pictures.  In the end though it comes down to the difference between the 3.8 zoom of the Canon and the 12 zoom of the Panasonic.

Reviews.Title: Excellent pocket cammera
Reviews.Author: L. Krasue
Reviews.Content: So far this camera has been very convenient.  The picture quality is very good and the 12X zoom is a very nice feature.  It fits in my shirt pocket. The view screen is clear and bright.

Reviews.Title: Best camera I've ever had!
Reviews.Author: Greg Woods
Reviews.Content: I bought the ZS7 about 10 days ago and I've been extremely pleased with it so far. The pictures turn out extremely clear and I mostly use the Intelligent Auto mode, which does a great job of determining the best settings for each place. I also use program mode, but have it set for 16:9 ratio for times when I want a landscape picture. The video is also extremely clear and the avchd makes very good quality videos. I've been trying to figure out how to edit the avchd in its native format, because when I import the video into iMovie it converts it into mov files, which degrade the video. So far I've just archived the avchd to my hard drive until I learn how to natively edit it.The GPS feature on the camera is a fun thing to play around with and in iPhoto I can see all the places I've taken photos at since I've got it, which have been all the way from Mexico to Lake Tahoe, CA. The GPS does seem to eat up the battery a little quicker than with it off, but it is definitely worth it for me. For those particular about battery life, but want the GPS info, there is an airplane mode in which the GPS only works when the camera is turned on, rather than even when it is off as it does in regular mode.I have not bought a case for it yet as I don't believe Panasonic makes one specifically for it and I haven't researched enough to find a perfectly fitting one. The only thing I regret is not buying a screen protector right away, because I ended up going on vacation the day after I got the camera and I didn't have much time to buy one. I would recommend everybody buy one asap. I noticed some minor scuffs on my lcd screen and this has been bugging me ever since. I've rubbed the screen with a lint free cloth numerous times to no avail. The camera fits easily in my pocket, though I keep a spare glasses case around it when I put it in my pocket (this has worked for the time being, the scuffs were because I put it in my pocket one time without the case). Overall this is a great little camera for the hobbyist at a reasonable price.

Reviews.Title: Convenient and easy to use automatically; steep learning curve for the rest
Reviews.Author: Edward Hirsch "Big Ed"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to supplement an older Canon A610 so I could have 1) a wider and longer telephoto lens, 2) the superior optics that a Leica lens supposedly offers, 3) about twice as many mega-pixels for what I had hoped would be higher resolution pictures, 4) image stabilization to reduce the effect of a slight tremor in my left, steadying hand, 5) HD movie shooting, and 6) GPS geo-tagging so I could take advantage of my Mac's iPhoto Places organization tool without having to insert that information manually.I've only been using the camera for a few weeks so this review is tentative at best. The camera does everything it's supposed to do quite well. I've been pleased with many of the pictures I've taken, some of which would have been impossible to take without the wide and long telephoto lens. But all in all I've been somewhat disappointed with picture quality. Don't get me wrong. It's quite good. It's just that my expectations were unrealistically high. I now fully realize that no matter how good a camera's optics and many features are, a small sensor, such as the one in just about every compact camera, will never produce images as sharp as a DSLR with a much larger sensor, not that anybody said it would. Just wishful thinking on my part. So I'm beginning to look at this camera as a learning tool for my next camera which might be a four thirds format Panasonic, like the G2, or a full fledged DSLR. That kind of camera, however, will never be as small, light and convenient to use as the ZS7 is. It's definitely a keeper.In addition to the small sensor, there are a few other factors that may have limited picture sharpness so far. When you take pictures in the most fully automated (iA) mode, the camera tends to take them at a very high shutter speed and fairly large aperture setting. That limits what's in sharp focus - the depth of field. You have better control of that in one of the manual or scene modes but the camera's lens doesn't have a very small aperture so there's a limit to how much you can compensate. At the opposite end, there's not a very large aperture size that lets in a lot of natural light so many low light or indoor pictures either require using the flash, taking them at a slower speed and running the risk of the subject moving, or boosting the sensitivity (ISO) which tends to add a lot of noise or graininess above 400.There is one quirk I read about in a review before I bought the camera but didn't take seriously enough. When taking landscape photos, the color of the sky and the tone of the rest of a scene depends greatly on which direction you're pointing the camera and perhaps the angle of the sun. Take pictures in front of you and the sky may be brilliantly blue with white fluffy clouds but turn 90 degrees and the next picture you take may have a much grayer sky with clouds that are less distinguishable. The first picture may look like it was taken on a bright sunny day but the second picture, taken just seconds later under the same conditions, may look like it was taken on a more overcast day. I'm curious to know if others have had this same experience with the ZS7 or any other camera.Although the software on the enclosed DVD isn't compatible with my Macintosh computer, the PDF manual on that disk can easily be copied on to any computer, including the Mac. I've printed the 176 page document but I much prefer using the on-screen manual in the Mac's Preview application since I can increase the size of the type and illustrations and when I click on any of the numerous references to other pages I go directly there. But like most manuals these days, this one is too content oriented and not sufficiently geared to performing certain tasks and solving certain problems. A better manual, preferably an interactive DVD with video, would provide access to all the relevant information but do a better job enabling the user to meet all the challenges an amateur photographer is likely to face. I'd even pay extra for that if it were offered as an accessory assuming, of course, it worked on both Macs and PCs.My Canon has a fully articulating LCD which means I can easily take pictures with it from low or high angles or even surreptitiously from the side. Fortunately, the ZS7's large, bright LCD can be seen from many angles but at a certain point over your head, down by your knees or at an acute angle to the side, you lose sight of what you're about to shoot which is inevitable with this kind of camera. Maybe some day a slightly thicker, heavier point and shoot camera will come with an articulating LCD.Since I'm the kind of person who wants to take advantage of most of the camera's numerous features and capabilities, I'll need to spend a lot more time reading the manual, engaging in trial and error picture taking, and comparing the results of using different modes and settings in a variety of situations. If my assessment of the camera changes one way or the other after doing that, I'll modify my review accordingly.

Reviews.Title: Sweeet
Reviews.Author: Carlos M. Recalde
Reviews.Content: Sharp photos.  Full control, as in my pro-level digital SLRs. Super compact.  Great view-display.  And all the fancy features that you could look for.  And from Amazon, at the lowest price around.  You just can't beat this camera.  I would consider giving it to my Mom, because it's that simple to use as a point and shoot.  AND, I would buy this again for myself, because I can work as a real photographer - if I want to.  Most importantly, it is the true carry-around camera that I was seeking, and now I don't have to rely on my phone camera for that one-the-spot need to capture an image.  (Something for which I cannot count on a full-sized SLR.)The lens has a dynamic range, and the focus is reasonably quick.  I have not found anything that I could not do with this camera (whether it was suppressing the flash, compensating exposure for back lighting; delaying the shutter; switching to aperture priority; you name it).  I find the interface quite intuitive (or at least it's in tune with my way of thinking), and I have not had to open the manual once.  Whether you're an intermediate or advanced shooter, you will enjoy the experience of using this camera, and will be very pleased with quality of it's images.  Even if you're just a beginner who likes to buy something you won't grow out of, this is a GREAT DEAL.  Highly recommended!!!

Reviews.Title: Lumix DMC-ZS7 camera
Reviews.Author: Leo-C
Reviews.Content: Ordered on Thursday and got it Monday.  Amazon is the best.  I buy everything I can thru them even if the price is slightly higher.  Panasonic has hit a home run with the ZS7.  I need a clear 25 mm wide lens on the bottom and clear 300 mm on the top for my work everyday.  Its solid all around, image stabilization is one of the best I've experienced, shoot it full automatic in iA mode or set exposure in P mode or full manual it that's your thing.  Incredible small size fits in a shirt pocket.In fact I liked it so much I bought another ZS7 in Red for my 92-year-old mother and she's taking photos with it now.

Reviews.Title: Create camera
Reviews.Author: Nathan Hoover
Reviews.Content: I've had the TZ3, TZ5, ZS3 and now the ZS7. The first two were only ok - video mode not good, but the ZS3 and ZS7 have fixed the video mode and just keep adding features. The GPS on the ZS7 works surprisingly well. Battery life is ok, and I bought a couple of Power2000 batteries that last quite a bit longer than the stock ones. I had bought some Hong Kong ones off eBay for the ZS3 which don't work on the ZS7 - that is a drag.I wish they had not moved to 12mp but am thankful they didn't go even higher like some of the competition. Image quality is just about as good as the ZS3 though so I can live with the larger files.I love the PASM modes - finally I have control of my photos! I still have to do a video experiment to see how long the new batteries last. The old ones lasted just enough to fill an 8GB card, about 70 minutes. Now I have a 16GB card and based on my experience so far with video I am guessing I can go longer than 70 minutes. I use the camera quite a bit for both stills and video.Great piece of work even though it isn't perfect - no camera is.

Reviews.Title: The DMC TZ5 was better
Reviews.Author: Judobear14
Reviews.Content: I've had a Lumix DMC TZ5 for almost two years and it is a wonderful camera and shoots amazing video.  The lens got scratched so I needed a replacement or repair, problem is that I was in Croatia and the warranty was running out.  Long story but I bought a new camera(DMC ZS7) through Amazon and sent it to a friend in the US who brought it over here to Europe and took my old camera back.  So far the new camera(ZS7) is not the newest latest greatest. I shoot video with my Canon HV20 and use the Lumix to catch those shots where I might not be hauling my bigger camera around.  I've had this camera for almost a month now and I don't think  the video on the ZS7 is anywhere close to the quality of what the TZ5 shot.  The colors are washed out and the pixelation is really bad.  I've tried so many different adjustments and it seems like it just doesn't do the job.  The other issue is that the Panasonic's AVCHD lite video format software is not supported on a Mac so I can't shoot video in this mode and load it onto my computer.  I am very disappointed and would send it back but that is impossible due to my continuing travel situation.  Probably looking for another camera.

Reviews.Title: Blurry pictures
Reviews.Author: vt "vt"
Reviews.Content: After seeing the 4 star rating and a good discount I bought this camera for my long vacation. But it turned out to be a huge mistake. I just cannot understand the good ratings people have given this product. It takes really bad and blurry pictures. It has GPS and good zoom and HD video etc. But the bottom line is that it takes bad pictures. No matter which setting you choose, if the picture is not taken in a broad daylight sun, it will come out very grainy and blurry.

Reviews.Title: Poor Night Picture Reliability
Reviews.Author: Joanne M. Dealmeida
Reviews.Content: Just gave Panasonic 2nd and last chance.  Previous TZ3 had an electronic problem from the beginning with freezing up requiring battery to be removed to reboot. Now pretty much inoperable.  Purchased a DMC-ZS7 and noticed the screen and picture quality progressively deteriorate when in night picture mode; blue circles/bubbles and unstable pixilation.  Too bad the quality of Panasonic is so poor.  Good concept poorly executed.  The second camera was returned to Costco and I got stuck with the first and no goodwill credit from Panasonic.

Reviews.Title: Dueling pocket super zooms: DMC-ZS7 versus Fuji F300EXR
Reviews.Author: R. Guilmette "ronbaby"
Reviews.Content: Hummm... where to begin.  I'm a very experienced amateur photographer.  My dad and I used to develop and print our own color film & prints in our basement darkroom, back 40 years ago when essentially zero amateurs even attempted this. I even worked for a short while (and got paid) as a photographer.  (But that also was a long time ago.)  Still, I know my way around a camera.I've owned several different film cameras in my life, but sold off the last one a few years ago because I could see the handwriting on the wall.  My first digital was an Olympus C-5000, which was nice, but only 5mp.  It had a couple of special features that I really miss.  I'll come back to those.  After that I got myself an Olympus SP-570UZ, in part because that is the ONLY model in the Olympus SP line that actually had a hotshoe for external flash.  I'll come back to that too.So anyway, recently I knew that I was going to be taking two trips, one of which was a rather challenging hike in Yosemite, so I decided to get myself something really compact and light.  Lucky for me I found not one by two big-zoom pocket compacts on sale as open box items in Amazon marketplace at ridiculous low prices.  (They have probably fired the guy who listed those by now, because really I got these both dirt cheap.)The first one I ordered was a Fuji Finepix F300EXR... basically last year's model, open box, at a knock down price.  This is another shirt-pocket big zoom compact (15x zoom, 12mp, 3.0" LCD).
