Then I saw the Lumix DMC-ZS7 (black)... also last year's model... on Amazon as a open box for an even more ridiculously low price, so I said "what the hell" and bought that one too, intended to return one of the other, depending on which one I liked best.  (I am a big fan of buying last year's model of anything and everything.  No matter what it is, this year's model is always overpriced, because all companies know that they can gouge the "early adopters".)So I got both and ran a few trivial picture quality comparisons and for both outdoor and indoor the DMC-ZS7 was quite clearly superior in terms of picture quality.  (I *did not* actually make any "low light" tests.  I feel obliged to mention that because the marketing materials for the Fuji assert that it gives markedly superior low-light performance.  I have not really checked this claim and thus can't say, one way or the other.)Both of these cameras are 12 megapixel models, but as I say, my own test shots, when displayed side-by-side on my monitor left no doubt.  Image quality was superior on the ZS7... perhaps not all that surprising of a result, given that the original MSRP at release was about a hundred bucks higher for the ZS7 versus the F300EXR.Size and weight of both cameras is essentially identical.  Both/either fit quite comfortably in a shirt pocket or a jeans pocket.  (Because these were my first ultra-compacts, I wasn't sure that would be true until I received them.)  Both are about the size of a pack of cigarettes, but a bit longer and only just barely thicker.  Both cameras have outer skins that are mostly metal, with some plastic trim here and there.  Both feel quite solid and build quality of both appears to my eye to be excellent.The F300EXR has slightly longer zoom (15x versus 12x) but given the choice, I'll take the better image quality over that extra zoom length.  Both cameras have nice 3.0 inch high-res LCDs, and both of those are sharp as a tack.  Both can take 720p high-res movies, and both have HDMI outputs.  (These were two features I really wanted.)  Both cameras come with essentially identical standard accessories, AV cable, USB cable, manual(s), software disks, and writs strap.  Both provide at least a modicum of manual controls... something else I definitely wanted... as well as shutter & aperture priority modes.Controls on both cameras are comfortable and, for the most part, intuitive.  The F300EXR has a kind of outer ring around the normative North/South/East/West/OK button set, and in playback and other contexts this is helpful.  The ZS7 doesn't have that, and to make matters worse the "legend", i.e. symbols indicating the function, that are on each of the North/South/East/West buttons pn the ZS7 are simply engraved into the tiny shiny metal buttons, making them very nearly impossible to even read in dim light (or actually impossible if I don't have my reading glasses on).The F300EXR power switch is push-down type, whereas on the ZS7 it is a slider switch.  (I prefer the latter.) On the F300EXR, the only way to playback is to power on (causing the lens to extend and the flash to pop up) and THEN press the playback button to switch to playback mode  This is clearly wasteful of time & battery power.  The ZS7 has a more sensible slider switch which can be set to either recording or playback mode BEFORE you slide the power switch to ON.As has been noted elsewhere, the F300EXR flash pops up and stays up whenever the power is on, and unfortunately, it is right win the spot where you are most likely to rest your left index finger. (You DO hold your cameras with both hands, right?)  By popping up, the F300EXR's flash maybe gets a tiny bit further from the lens (thus reducing red eye?) but I doubt this "feature" really buys you much.  The flash on the ZS7 is just there on the front of the camera.  No pop-up action.  Anyway, the pop-up flash on the F300EXR is not really annoying, just a bit surprising sometime when you power on and feel a little pushing up under your left index finger.On the ZS7, I noted that my left index finger sort-of naturally came to rest often on the upper left front corner of the camera.  That's not a problem until the camera wants to use the infrared thingy to help with auto-focus, at which point your'll note immediately that you need to move your left index finger slightly to get it out of the way of the infrared.The menu system of the F300EXR is quite good. It's clear, easy to read, dark-gray/light-gray superimposed over whatever would otherwise be displayed on the LCD at the moment.  The menu system of the ZS7, yellow-on-white, didn't seem quite as nice to me, but both/either will get the job done.  One major irritant with both of these that could easily be rectified by the manufacturers is a missing feature that I have on my Olympus SP-570UZ, i.e. built-in verbose help pages/screens within the menu system.  On the SP-570UZ, if you don't understand or are not sure about the function of some setting or another, you are just one tap away from a very helpful verbose English language description of the function of that setting.  It's almost like carrying a condensed/abridged version of the manual around with you, only better.  Why all digital cameras don't have this feature is beyond me.  It really doesn't take up much memory OR require much programming and even the simplest digital cameras nowadays are so complex and have so many features and functions that most have manuals that go on for more than 100 pages.  Are we supposed to MEMORIZE all that before sallying forth into the field to take pictures??  I think not.  So put it in the camera!  That way we can't lose it, like that bleedin' lens cap we haven't seen in the last five years.The super deluxe let-me-do-it-all-for-you point-and-shoot automatic-everything modes on both cameras produced generally excellent results in a variety of situations and conditions.  To my eye, auto-focus, auto-exposure, and auto white balance on both cameras pretty much always produced acceptable results, however as I've said, I am old-school, and where "auto with aperture priority" on small cameras such as these, where you can't really get thin depth of field no matter what you do (because the lenses are just too tiny), seem like an entirely useless/superfluous setting, I did feel the need to try auto with shutter priority on both cameras for various shots, just to keep the respective "intelligent" auto modes from mucking up the shot with excessively optimistic shutter speeds that wouldn't actually work in practice, especially handheld, towards the long ends of the zoom ranges.Battery life on both the F300EXR and the ZS7 was beyond excellent, and seemed to me to be well beyond what you would ever need for any one sitting OR even for an entire short vacation.  I mean who on earth takes 250+ shots in one sitting?  I'm an old-school guy who grew up on film cameras and who always had to worry about running out of film.  8GB SDHC cards are dirt cheap, so if you get one of those, then really, in the modern digital era, the only thing you ever really need to worry about running out of is battery power.  But as I say, with these cameras it seems like you don't even really need to worry about that much either.  I'm paranoid, so I bought an extra (cheaper than Panasonic) third-party spare battery for the ZS7, and now I feel like an idiot for having done so, because really, I doubt that I'll ever even use it.  I took about 100 shots on an all-day hike in Yosemite and I still had plenty of power left at the end of the day.  Today I did my 31+ minute test movie, and even that didn't move the needle on the battery charge indicator... a rather surprising result given that modern video compression is known to be rather CPU (and power) intensive.The two Olympus cameras I had before I bought these two shirt-pocket compacts were straightforward to get pictures and movies from, even when I was plugging them into my UNIX system.  Both cameras just acted like a USB drive, with a FAT filesystem and so forth, and both could be "mounted" as a drive on UNIX or even,,, yecch... Windoze.  I assumed that all digital cameras behaved this way nowadays, but I was disappointed to learn that the F300EXR doesn't work this way.  Instead, it speaks some protocol called PTP.  In order to get stuff directly off the camera (from FreeBSD) I was going to have to load some additional software and diddle several system settings.  Blecch. I never did.  Instead I just bought myself a cheapie SD/SDHC card reader.  Problem solved.  On the other hand, the ZS7 _does_ behave just like a USB drive, so I could just plug it in, mount it as a drive, and start pulling stuff off.  I like that.  It's simple.The ZS7 has three features that definitely set it apart from the Fuji F300EXR, i.e. GPS, stereo sound recording, and the ability to record movies with some modern flavor of data compression, specifically AVCHD.  Personally, I don't give a flying fig about the GPS.  It's been set to off since I got the camera.  (I _do_ already know what city I am in, thank you very much.)  If I can ever figure out how to get actual GPS _coordinates_ out of the ZS7, and not just city names, then I will think that the GPS might have some usefulness, e.g. for the unlikely day I am lost in the forest with a satellite phone and need to tell my rescuers where I am.  But as I have so far not seen any setting on the ZS7 that would give me raw GPS hours/minutes/seconds coordinates, I still don't see the GPS feature as being at all useful, even with the GPS picture-tagging feature. I mean hey!  If I have a shot of Half Dome, I think I can remember that I took in in Yosemite.  If I'm looking at a shot I took of the Eiffel Tower... well... umm... DUH!  GPS is obviously just one of those techno bells and whistles that camera designers add just because they can, cheaply, and because the guys in the marketing departments think that it sounds techno-cool.  There are at least half a dozen OTHER features that could be added to these kinds of cameras for one tenth the cost and that would actually help people to take better pictures, but those ones don't seem to make it into the designs for some reason.  (See rant below.)The ability to record stereo sound is likewise rather superfluous, in my opinion.  I mean seriously, you have two microscopic microphones and they are sitting about 1/2 inch from one another.  Do we really think that the left and right are going to hear anything significantly different from the other?  If you do, then I have a bridge to sell you.Lastly, the modern video compression and the AVCHD recording format actually were and are things that I really cared/care about and want/wanted. I just now did a 30+ minute 720p/30 test recording on the ZS7.  (Yes, apparently the ZS7 _does not_ have the seemingly arbitrary 29 point something minute per movie time limit that some other digital cameras I've read about have.)  Anyway, my little 31+ minute ZS7 720p/30fps test recording came out to just over 3.6GB on the SDHC card.  That seems to me to be not too shabby, but as this is the first and only digital camera I've ever owned that can record HD or even SD movies, I really have nothing to compare it against.  Oops!  Wait a minute!  I almost forgot the F300EXR!OK so I did a 720p/24fps test recording using the F300EXR.  I just shot for about 11 minutes.  The resulting (AVI aka "motion JPEG") file size came out to about 1.25GB.  So ummm... hummm... maybe the newer fancy schmancy compression of AVCHD ain't all that big of an advantage, filesize-wise, after all.  I mean if you ignore the fact that one camera (ZS7) was recording 30 frames per second and the other one (F300EXR) was only recording 24fps, then the file sizes divided by the length of the recordings actually seem to come out to a fairly comparable number for either camera (and/or either type of compression used), i.e somewhat over 1GB per ten minutes of 720p recording.  BUT WAIT!  We need to consider the relative quality of the recordings also. I'll discuss and compare that below.I should note also that for my two test movie recordings for the ZS7 and the F300EXR I had the cameras on a tripod, pointed in a fixed direction into my backyard, and there was no zooming.  Many ducks and Canada geese wandered in and out of the frame during the recording, but other than that, the subject matter was certainly highly redundant/compressible.  In short, if I had done these test recordings by just pointing the camera out of the side of a moving train, I think I could safely bet that the resulting video files would have been substantially bigger than these ones actually came out to be.Oh!  Did I mention that both the F300EXR and the ZS7 allow zooming during movies?  (On the ZS7 you don't hear the zooming at all on the recording, but on the F300EXR you do, but just a little.)As I alluded to above, both the ZS7 and the F300EXR can be connected to your big modern flat screen TV via a special HDMI cable.  Neither camera ships with one of these, but the cables can be had for a few bucks each off Amazon.  (Do I need to warn you to make sure you order the Right Kind for your specific camera?)The ZS7 shoots all movies resolutions, including 720p, at 30 frames per second.  The ZS7 gives a choice of recording in "motion JPEG" (AVI?) format, AVCHD format, or AVCHD format annotated with GPS info. The F300EXR shoots 720p only a 24 frames per second and will record only in motion JPEG (AVI) format. AVCHD definitely should, in theory at least, provide better and more modern compression and thus considerably smaller movie files.  But see below.My short 720p test recordings on the ZS7, when played back via my LG BD370 and Samsung 42 inch 720p plasma were OK, but not what I would call stunning as regards to clarity.  Close ups of a cat in the garden who wasn't moving all that much were, ummm, acceptable, but it appears to me that when some of the branches (and leaves) of my local oak tree were in the shot, and when the leaves were moving on account of a passing breeze, or when I was panning or zooming, the complexity of the images was pushing the outer envelope of the video compression and/or the recording bit rate.  The oak leaves definitely did not appear to me to be crystal clear.  If you are not too critical, the the ZS7 will do just fine at 720p/30/ACVHD for your cat, your kids, or your family barbecue, and will definitely produce results that are likely better than any standard-def videocam, if only just.I, for one, have never been a believer in the advantages of 1080 over 720 HD.  Unless you routinely sit two feet away from your big flat screen with one of those 8 1/2 x 11 Fresnel sheet magnifiers, you are really never going to notice any advantage of 1080 over 720.  For me, even my local stations, when viewed in 720p on my Samsung 720p plasma are sharp as a tack. 1080 HD is mostly just a marketing thing designed to separate consumers from their excess money.I mention all this only because I want you to know that if you are expecting "broadcast quality" 720p from either the ZS7 or the F300EXR you ARE going to be disappointed.  These pockatable cameras are just not going to give you the same clarity as a dedicated professional videocam costing 50 times as much.  But like I say, these cameras will still give you acceptable video of the family barbecue. (These kinds of higher-end pocket digital cameras are really the modern equivalent of the old family 8mm camera of bygone days... but actually a bit less sharp, I'm sad to report.)All that being said, the 720p/24fps recordings created by the F300EXR were definitely and obviously not in the same class as the 720p/30fps test recordings I did with the ZS7.  And no, I do not think that this was just a matter of the difference in the frame rate.  The test recordings from the ZS7 definitely appeared as if they had been shot with higher resolution, relative to the test recordings produced by the F300EXR.  But don't get too excited.  As I said above, neither of these cameras produces anything that could be mistaken for "broadcast quality" 720p.  Still, in comparable 720p recordings, the ZS7 produces unambiguously and noticeably sharper and clearer results, relative to the F300EXR.  (But I would be happy to take either camera, any day, and by a country mile, over any cellphone-cam.)Other points on video recording...The F300EXR apparently has a "feature" (aka bug) in the audio recording.  I noticed this when I did some test recording in my backyard.  Whenever the ducks and geese got really quiet and when the traffic noise from the nearby major arterial subsided, and when there were no planes overhead, in short when things got mostly quiet, the F300EXR apparently invoked some sort of demented auto level adjustment algorithm that causes the recording to go dead quiet, at least until the actual sound you are recording picks up a bit again.  On playback, these dead quiet periods were really noticeable, and seemed, well, odd.  The ZS7 has no such mis-feature.I really wanted the ACVHD recording feature of the ZS7 because I have both an older Panasonic Blu-Ray player (DMP-BD60) and also a medium old LG Blu-Ray player (BD370) that both claimed to be  able to play ACVHD, and I wanted to see if I could record some stuff in ACVHD format, burn it to a DVD, and then play it on one or both of these Blue-Ray players.  Well, I can now report that I _have_ been able to do exactly this.  I took two short 720p test recordings made in the ACVHD mode on the ZS7, used the software that came with the ZS7, copied the recordings to the hard drive on my Windoze7 system, and then used the software that came with the ZS7 to burn both recordings to a single DVD, and then popped that into my LG BD370, and it just worked, with even a little top-level menu that allowed me to select which of the two test recordings to play.  That's the good news.The bad news is that it was almost impossible to do all this because of at least a couple of really atrocious bugs in the Panasonic PHOTOfunStudio 5.1 HD software that came with the camera.  The worst of these bugs was that on Windows7, at least, critical buttons like "next" and "back" and "ok" and "abort" that appear at various points during interaction with the software *are not even readable*!!  I'm not kidding.  The titles that should appear on these buttons actually display as black characters on a black background!!  So I ended up having to look at the PDF of the camera manual, and at its screen shots of the software in operation, in order to deduce which of the several completely black buttons on the screen was actually the "back" button, which one was the "next" button, and so forth.  Without the camera's PDF manual and its screen shots, the PHOTOfunStudio 5.1 HD  software would have been totally un-navigable and thus totally useless, and I would not have been able to get my ACVHD recordings off the SDHC card OR subsequently burn them onto a DVD. In short, PHOTOfunStudio 5.1 HD is seriously broken.  I groped around for a long time on Panasonic's web site and eventually found a version 5.2, downloaded it and tried to install it and the install process failed with some utterly mysterious and entirely uninformative error message.  De-installing 5.1 before trying to install 5.2 made no difference.  (Panasonic needs to hire some monkeys to test their camera-external software.  Even a monkey could see that both PHOTOfunStudio 5.1 and PHOTOfunStudio 5.2 have critical flaws.)  At the time of this writing I don't even know yet whether I will be able to even reinstall the 5.1 version successfully or not.  At least I could get it to burn my ACVHD movies onto DVDs, albeit only while working around the unlabeled back/next/etc. buttons.  But I can't even get 5.2 to install!  Even stranger, Panasonic's web site talks about various 6.x versions of this same PHOTOfunStudio software, but I'll be bleeped if I can even find where they might be hiding those versions on their web server, let alone anything on the Panasonic web site that says what the differences might be between the different versions OR anything which lists which versions are compatible with which Lumix camera models.)(NOTE: The ONLY reason I am giving the ZS7 four rather than five stars is because of all of these unforgivable external software snafus.)Just a few final complaints about the Fuji F300EXR the ZS7, and probably every other pockatable digital camera currently on the market... (begin rant mode).Firstly, I know these things are already both tiny and packed to the rafters with internal guts, but seriously, how hard would it be for thje manufacturers to add a little optical or digital viewfinder, or alternatively, in the absence of that, to make and sell a reasonably priced thing that fits over the LCD, shades it, and provides a small lens with a diopter adjustment?  Despite the marketing hype, these LCDs are utterly useless in the presence of bright sun.  You just can't frame a shot with the sun behind you.  Just as importantly, it seems that everybody who designs these kinds of pocketable digitals is under the age of 45.  I say that because obviously, not a single one of them knows the first thing about presbyopia.  I am over 45, have presbyopia (like everybody else my age) and I can't be talking with my friends, ten feet in front of me, and then look down at the LCD on my camera, one foot in front of my face, and see it other than as a big blur, at least until I put my reading glasses back on, by which time I have missed the moment AND the shot.  This sucketh. I've seen shade thingies on sale that fit over 3 inch LCDs and have little diaopter adjustable lenses, and these would be perfect for people like me and our pocket cameras, but alas, these things are mostly sold to the DSLR crowd and thus cost and arm and a leg.  SOMEBODY should make and sell them for $19.95 (please?)  That would still yield a 10,000% profit over manufacturing cost.My (now ancient) Olympus C-5000 had a little optical viewfinder.  That proves that it can be done, and indeed, that technology is actually regressing in some ways.  the C-5000 had a viewfinder and that was 6+ years ago!  This new generation of pockatable cameras, unlike my C-5000 from 6 years ago, are (a) useless in bright sun and (b) semi-useless to the 99.9% of people over age 45 who need/use reading glasses.Another useful feature that my old C-5000 had that I seriously miss, and that I'm 100% sure would be dirt cheap to add to this current generation of pocket cameras was a tiny little infrared remote control.  2-second and 10-second delay timers just don't cut it if you want to get in the shot with all your pals AND have time to compose yourself and smile your best smile.  Also, I want to be able to set my camera on the other side of the garden and then fire it remotely from inside the house when and if I see some wildlife passing right in front of it.  Again, technology is regressing.  I had a remote control 6+ years ago.  Now I don't. :-(  Why?  They are cheap to make and the IR camera sensor already has to be there anyway, for the IR-based auto-focus assist.More absent features...It's too bad the designers of the current generation of pockatables are all boxed into the amateur "snapshot" mindset.  I guess that we should be grateful that they at least include tripod mounts on these cameras, even if only as an afterthought.  But come on!  If you are going to build a camera with a tripod mount, then it is almost idiotic that the user can't even tell the whole "intelligent auto" fly-by-wire almost-artificial-intelligence master brain/computer that "Hey! We are tripod mounted now, so you, camera-brain, can automagically select slower shutter speeds and thus, correspondingly lower auto-computed ISO settings (for less noise)."  In short, there should be a "tripod mounted" setting which will modify the settings selected by the "intelligent auto" system. (It doesn't count as "intelligent" if the camera doesn't know what even the stupidest human knows, i.e. that the camera is tripod mounted and thus more stable and jitter-free.)  In a similar/related vein, why can't these designers of pockatable cameras include some facility for plugging in the electronic equivalent of a good old fashioned shutter-release cable, you know, for when you are tripod mounted AND when you want to do shutter release without even touching... or jiggling... the camera?  I was able to buy a cheapie third-party "electronic" shutter-release thingy for my semi-old SP-570UZ and it worked like a charm and was dirt cheap.  It plugs into the SP570UZ's USB connector, so no extra precious camera surface area was needed in the design of this on the camera side.  This is SOOOOOO technically trivial, and yet so useful to anybody who really cares about getting a rock-solid non-blurred shot that it is a travesty for ANY digital camera not to have support for this kind of optional external accessory.  I mean it's like buying an expensive BMW and then looking down where the cigarette lighter should be and just seeing an empty hole.  Dumb.  Really dumb.More stuff I wish I could have...Connectors:  Now that these pockatable cameras are getting big zooms and other higher-end features, how about thinking outside of the box and providing just some cheap/easy but potentially extremely useful connectors, specifically (a) a good old fashioned flash "sync cord" socket and/or (b) a micro phone jack / TRS jack where an external stereo microphone could be plugged in?  Either of these would be technically trivial and dirt cheap to add, so how about it manufacturers?You manufacturers really don't have to worry about these extra features causing "cannibalization" of your higher-end (and more expensive) DSLR or super-zoom bridge camera lines for the simple reason that the markets for these things are just plain DIFFERENT MARKETS.  Anybody planning a trip deep into the amazon rain forest and who wants the best photos he can get IS going to buy a DSLR, no matter what nice little tweaks he can get on a pocket portable.  Conversely, anybody going into the jungle and who just wants some snapshots to take home is NOT going to spring for a DSLR or an expensive bridge camera... or be willing to carry the extra weight... just so he can get an external mic jack or an electronic shutter release.  Different markets.  'nuff said.Here endith the lesson.Other than the above nits, I actually love both the F300EXR and the ZS7.  They are both stunning and phenomenal pieces of engineering.  But of the two, the ZS7 is the one I will be keeping.P.S. One other small nit about digital cameras generally and the ZS7 and F300EXR specifically. All the digital cameras I've ever owned, including these two news ones are all apparently too stupid to even know which way is up.  Literally.  Can't you manufacturers fix this??  iPhones seem to always know which way is up, so why can't all digital cameras?(Like many of the comments above, the following comments are addressed to the camera manufacturers.)Look, this is very simple guys.  Every JPEG file has a built-in orientation and thus, a built in "upper left" corner.  So why is it that when I take my digital camera and orient it vertically, you know, as in "portrait" orientation versus "landscape" orientation, and then I take a shot and then load the JPEG onto my PeeCEE and then try and view the thing, the picture shows up on my screen lying on its side, rather than oriented properly?  This is definitely YOUR FAULT for not writing the JPEG file in way so that it will have proper (gravity based?) orientation.This is beyond stupid, particularly because I know for a fact that both the ZS7 and the F300EXR do in fact know which way is up, and they just aren't using that information properly.  I know they know which way is up, because in default factory settings on both, when I play back any JPEG that was shot "portrait" (vertical) it shows on the LCD in ``proper'' orientation, i.e. holding the camera normally (horizontal orientation) and then playing back a vertical-orientation shot, these cameras re-orient the images so that they appear on the LCDs vertically, and with big wide black bands on either side.  To accomplish this, obviously both cameras must be adding some sorts of annotations to all JPEGs they produce which indicate whether the shot was taken horizontally or vertically.  So the cameras do know which was is "up" for any given shot.  And they even save notes about that for each shot/JPEG.  Unfortunately, both cameras are too dumb to simply arrange for the JPEGs themselves to be oriented properly, based on which was is up and which way is down at the time the shot was taken.  That's dumb.  Really dumb.P.P.S.  Lowepro Ridge 30 cases fit either of the cameras described above perfectly.  DO NOT try to get a Ridge 20, based on the interior size specs and the exterior size specs for these cameras. First, you will have trouble finding a Ridge 20, because apparently, they don't make them anymore.  And as I learned, even if you get one, you will wish you hadn't, because they are so tight that it will be a chore getting either of these cameras in or out of the case.  Go with the Ridge 30, which is just slightly roomier, and thus perfect for either of these cameras.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera, Mac Users Be Advised
Reviews.Author: Paul G.
Reviews.Content: First off, this is a fantastic camera.  I've owned the TZ5 and loved it (it met an unfortunate demise at the hands of my 2 year-old son).  This camera follows and improves upon the Lumix DMC line splendidly.  As a prosumer photographer, what impresses me most about this compact is the quality of the lens, and Leica glass is hard to beat.  I've taken shots with this camera that rival shots taken with my DSLR.  This is a small camera that packs an enormous punch with it's high-quality lens.  It's fantastic for travel, and I take it mountaineering with me when my DSLR's weight is too prohibitive.The one warning I would give to potential buyers is that the AVCHD Lite format is NOT inherently Mac compatible (not yet, anyway)!  Your two options if you use a Mac are to shoot video in the JPG mode, or to buy software that will convert AVCHD Lite files to .mp4 or .mov files.  Neither option is incredibly enticing, nor does Panasonic make it very clear in it's promotional literature that the camera's much touted AVCHD Lite format is not readily usable on a Mac.

Reviews.Title: Hiker's Delight
Reviews.Author: Cactus Bill
Reviews.Content: After 40 years in newsrooms, I developed a decent eye for good images. But taking my own has always been another matter altogether. I'm a rank novice at that. So I wanted a camera that compensated for my unsteady hand, did a lot of the work for me and performed well in a wide range of circumstances, particularly on the hiking trails of Arizona. The Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 I got for Christmas hits the mark on every count. For users like me, the measure is how often you find yourself saying, "Geez, I took that!" Thanks to its Leica lens and image stabilization, the images have been razor sharp, beautifully exposed both indoors and out and the GPS feature has worked very well on hikes. I was concerned about reviews that noted how taxing the GPS was because it remains on even when the camera is off. But studying the manual, I learned that if it's turned off while the camera is on, it does not sap power when the camera is turned off. I have had no problems so far with battery life. But keep in mind I'm an amateur, not a high end user shooting hundreds of shots on each outing. The camera does very well indoors even without flash. For active outdoor users, it's compact size is a great feature. It's easy to carry in a small case or in a pocket while hiking. And the pictures are spectacular. My 20-year-old son and I hiked to the top of Southern Arizona's Pusch Peak during the holidays. We perched the camera on a rock at the top and, using the delay feature, took what I treasure as the best picture ever taken of the two of us. I took one of him standing on a rock overlooking all of Tucson and was stunned at how beautifully it came out. None of this should impress experienced photographers. But for those of you looking for a camera that can make novices look quite good, this one's a feature rich option at a very attractive price. I love it!

Reviews.Title: Wonderful camera
Reviews.Author: R. Van Meter "Dick in Upper Arlington"
Reviews.Content: I researched this camera on the internet.  I originally wanted the Samsung HZ35W camera.  It has 15x zoom and GPS tagging.  But in reviews of camera, you have to download the maps and store them on a SD card.  Also some professional reviewers of the Samsung said it has noisy photos at higher ISOs.  The Panasonic DMC-ZS7 is the same camera as the Leica V-LUX 20, but at a substantially lower price.  It has up to 16x in optical zoom and higher if you turn on digital zoom.  It has built in GPS and the maps are preloaded.  The GPS can only be turned on and off through the menu screen.  In the Samsung it has a separate switch which would be handy on the Panasonic.  The Panasonic GPS continues to draw power even when the camera is shut off.  So you have to think about it when you put it away.  I wish Panasonic had put a switch to turn on and off the GPS.The Panasonic has the Leica lens so the pictures are wonderful in clarity.  One feature I really like is the manual record/play switch.  Where you can stay in playback or in record as long as you want.  It also has a instant video red button that allows you to start recording video at a moment's notice, without changing and selector knobs on top of the camera.  There is a separate button for sending unwanted photos to the trash can with on screen confirmation.I have taken several photos and found the camera easy to handle.  I have used the GPS feature but the camera doesn't give me confirmation until playback that shows the city, state, and country on the photo record, but won't record it on a print unless you tell it to.  It has manuel capabilities in case you want to tinker with the exposure settings like shutter priority, and aperture priority, and of course full manuel.  If you want to have the camera fix red eye you have to change the menu in Program mode and the camera does a nice job.  It flashes once to allow the subject's pupil to close down before the main flash to take the picture.  Many other cameras use multiple flashes before the main flash.  Red eye is caused by the flash being too close to the lens, and reflects the blood in the eyes.If you are looking for a great camera with a very good lens the Panasonic DMC-ZS7 is hard to beat for a higher end pocket camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: RKR
Reviews.Content: I used this camera for a trip to Europe.  The picture quality was great.  Here are the pros 1.  The scenery setting has multiple options such as snow, night scenery, food, etc.  Changing the setting is fast and easy, 2.  The camera is ready to take a picture nearly instantly when the camera is turned on.  3. The GPS was a great option and very accurate.  It was easy to turn on and off if you want to conserve the battery.  There is a quick menu function to do this. 4. The battery lasted a very long time.  I only had to charge it on average once every 3 days and I had the GPS running all the time. 5.  Video quality is good.  I took a video of the Glockenspiel in Munich and the quality was very good considering that this is primarily a still photo camera.  6. The low-light photos were very good.  I have not found too many cons with it except the software it came with.  The software feels like something that was very cheaply done.  I do not have a lot of patience with electronics that are difficult to use.  This camera is light weight, easy to use, and it takes better pictures then any other camera I owned including a Minolta, Cannon, Kodak, and Fuji.  I highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Pleased as Punch
Reviews.Author: Glenn
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera with more zoom. After checking out camera reviews at various sites I narrowed my choice down to a Canon (SX210ISA) and a Lumix (ZS7). I then went to a store to see and feel both. The store had the Canon and a ZS5, which is a scaled down version of the ZS7. I liked both cameras, but the Lumix remained in focus when I zoomed, while the Canon took some time to refocus.I purchased the ZS7 from Amazon and it works as promised. The battery life after the first charge was pathetic; however, the battery is still going strong since the second charge so I don't think there is a problem. I keep the GPS turned off to conserve battery life, but will turn it back on when I travel. The ZS7 connects to my Apple computer and the photos are downloaded by iPhoto and the video clips are downloaded and played by iMovie - no need to use the software provided on the CD. I did print out the operating manual - there is a lot to read if you want to use all the bells and whistles that come with the ZS7. I am still in the point and shoot mode and the camera automatically does what it needs to to make a great picture. The sunset pictures are better than the real thing. The video is great also. The image stabilization works well. The ZS7 is the same size as my previous camera so I am able to put a camera with much more capability in the same carrying case.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera
Reviews.Author: Jackson49
Reviews.Content: Purchased this camera before a Disney World Vacation where I wanted to be able to take still and video, but did not want to carry two cameras or a large video camera.  The Lumix DMC-ZS7 was perfect and can be carried easily in a case securely fastened to your belt (see Tuff Luv cases). Takes great stills and video and with the 16gb SD cards can easily store a days worth of pictures and video.  You can also carry an extra card if you are expecting to take lots of HD video.  The size of the camera although not as small as some is easy to hold securely for telephoto shots.  The 12x zoom was great for shooting closeups of the Grandchildren.  I was able to shoot in low light with good results and the stabilization feature works better than I expected.  Some reviewers were disappointed with the battery life so I carried a spare battery in my pocket, but it was not needed.  The battery life is shorter if the GPS is on, but it can be turned off easily.  At Disney World the GPS was great as it labelled the shots by the individual theme park.Would recommend for anyone looking for a small camera with a big zoom which you can take anywhere that can take good stills and video.  Amazon delivery was so good, my son purchased one a week before the trip and it arrived without a problem.

Reviews.Title: Very nice camera, GPS is great
Reviews.Author: C. Eades "Happy with Product"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for one reason only, the GPS.  I have had other Lumix cameras and enjoyed the picture quality of them.  This camera is no exception.  It's well and sturdily build, the picture quality (a Leica lens for crying out loud!) for both still and video is above average, and the GPS is a very fun thing.Why do I want GPS?  Because when you upload to iPhoto, or perhaps another website, they will read the GPS information encoded on the picture and pop up a map so viewers of your pictures can see exactly where you were.  No more "Gee, was that Rome or Florence?  As they flip through your pictures, the map pin will move to indicate the change in coordinates. The camera itself has a built in database of "Points of Interest" which is pretty amazing.  I was able to tell our host the names of things they didn't know because the camera can display that information for you.  Not only that, it uses the GPS info to set it's internal clock and calendar.  It's more accurate than my old watch!  The GPS information is also recorded when you take video (HiDef video at that!).So, for less than $300 you can get a high quality, zoom camera that is probably smarter than you.  It's a deal!The only downside (if there is one) is that the included battery is not that great.  The aftermarket battery will last you much, much longer and doesn't cost much at all.  But you can get along fine with the stock battery.  You will just have to make sure you take your charger (a very small device) with you if you're going to take pics for more than a day.  You can also maximize your battery by turning the GPS update feature off.  In that case you'll get average battery life.Also - It doesn't come with a case, but I was able to get a really nice leather case on eBay for .99!  I thought it would just be so so, but its nice high quality leather, embossed with the Lumix name and came with one long strap and one smaller strap.

Reviews.Title: Shockingly Good Camera!!!
Reviews.Author: rimalaw
Reviews.Content: I bought both this Pana ZS7 and the Sony HX5V. I really wanted to love the Sony and thought that was my dream camera. It will cost me even more to return it than the Pana, so it pained me at first to love the Pana more. However... The Pana ROCKS!!! I cannot believe how stunning the photos come out with NO tweaking or playing with controls. Much clearer , VIBRANT, and Crispier than the Sony. The Pana has all manual controls, though for the true photo enthusiast who wants to play around with settings and have some very close DSLR features in a small package. You can check Amazon for both cameras to see uploaded photos that will show you just how great this camera is. It is even great in low light!!The Video Quality on the Pana is unbelievable, especially in low light. I could not believe how much brighter and better it was than the Sony! I mean Sony is 1080 and the Pana is 720, but WOW! The Sony did have some nice daytime clips, but overall, the Pana was just SUPERIOR. It was sad for me to see such a difference... You can even go to YouTube and type Panasonic ZS7 v. Sony Hx5v and see the multiple video comparisons. It will really help you see the difference; and yes it is accurate as I made my own comparisons.I took both out the other night to a party and compared the cameras and hands down the Pana was PHENOMINAL!!! Everyone there was saying how now they wanted that camera...Also, I tried out the burst at night in a dim room and could not believe how many photos it shot in a row without distortion! At least 30 were just shooting off. I had to finally lift my finger as it was just on a shooting frenzy.My only complaint is the button to switch back and forth for preview to shoot pics again and I wish it had the Sony Panarama Feature. The Pana has a Panarama Assist which I have not figured out yet if it will stich the photo in the camera like the Sony.Also, this camera is a nice size and you can easily keep this in your purse without feeling bulky (or belt area). I love that I don't have to bring along my Great DSLR when I want to take great pictures with long zoom or for a really special event or occasion.What can I say, if you buy this camera, you will be amazed, and know that I have reviewed all the quality cameras in this class and can tell you that after many sleepless review reading and testing nights, this is the CAMERA of the YEAR!!! If photo and video quality are important to you, then there is no question, five of five! It ROCKS and is A SHOCKINGLY AWESOME CAMERA!!! Just buy it if you can afford it.

Reviews.Title: Worst indoor and low light performance for an expensive camera
Reviews.Author: Ashok Krishnamoorthy "Ashok all over the US"
Reviews.Content: This camera is absolutely wonderful if you are using it outdoors with plenty of light.On the other hand it is atrocious indoors and in low light conditions. When I mean atrocious you can't take even decent looking pictures indoors even during daytime with plenty of light. Why would somebody buy a camera that takes only good outdoor pictures when 50% of your pictures will typically be indoors?All the other features of this camera are good.But beware of the quality of pictures. They are BAD and I mean it, particularly indoors.BTW I returned this camera in 3 days.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Wendy Richardson
Reviews.Content: I am completely novice in photography, but I needed a new camera and I mostly take photos of my two young children who never, ever, stop for breath.So I bought this one after reading reviews, and I love it.  It's always in focus, acts super-quickly when I need it to, and the quality of what prints off in the end is excellent.One thing I find frustrating is that you have to remove the battery to charge it, I would prefer to plug the camera itself in somewhere.  But the battery is pretty dependable anyway.Also you have to use the CD Rom for instructions past the point of setting up and click-shoot, also difficult when you have kids racing around the house and you want a quick answer.All-in-all I really like it.Very small, extremely easy to use, great quality photos.

Reviews.Title: Quit working after light usage
Reviews.Author: Dan
Reviews.Content: I have had this product for two years. It used to take good photos when it was working. I have not used the camera very much, but recently I received a "Focus Error" message "Turn off Camera and Turn On Again." I looked online and saw that many other people have had the same problem with this camera.  I called Panasonic, and they said it would cost $180 to have repaired. Disappointed in a product that doesn't last.

Reviews.Title: great compact camera
Reviews.Author: cowboy
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera before our trip to Hawaii. Has a great zoom pictures was able to take pictures of birds and waterfalls that were very far away and the pics turned out great. Only thing it does not have which I would have preferred is an independent viewer since when the sun is bright it is hard to see the LCD screenOther than that love it and would definitely recommend it

Reviews.Title: perfect
Reviews.Author: traveler
Reviews.Content: This is without any doubt the best camera in the 'small camera class'. It` s easy to use and has so many options. Great deal!

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: bree "bree"
Reviews.Content: I did a LOT of research before buying this Lumix camera, i am a long time user of a Nikon D 60, and was looking for a small camera with good video quality, after reading review after review and comparing camera's, I decided to give this one a try,  I have to tell you, the video is amazing, my $600 camcorder can't even compare to the quality of the video I get from this camera,I recently went to a concert and took a lot of video, I was not sitting very close at all, but the quality of the video looks like I was, sharp, clear and playback looks just like you are watching a movie on TV.I have had this camera for about a month or so, and cannot think of one negative thing to say about it, I would buy it again in a hearbeat, it will be with me at all times, even when I am using my Nikon.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for HD video recording
Reviews.Author: jimmylin
Reviews.Content: There are already some great Amazon reviews on this camera, so I will add my portion with a focus on HD video recording.Let me mention that I purchased this camera with the primary intent of recording HD videos for badminton practices and tournaments. These events are always held inside large gyms, lit up by several large bright lights that do an adequate job of lighting up the gym. My criteria were as follows:1. 720p or greater HD video recording2. Must be able to continuously record for at least 30mins3. Pocket-size (I didn't want a bulky digital camcorder or DSLR)4. Good still picture-taking qualities are a bonus (I didn't want a Flip video recorder)5. Reasonable price, <$200Here's how the Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 satisfies my requirements:1. It records 720p HD video in two formats: AVCHD and Motion JPG2. The AVCHD format allows it to record 720p video indefinitely, given enough memory (on a 16GB SDHC card, the battery runs out at 1 hour 40 mins, while the card can support 2 hours of video)3. It's not a slim camera that you can easily slip into your jeans, but still a compact digital that feels good in your hand and doesn't require a separate camera bag.4. While it doesn't take the best pictures under low light conditions, it does quite well in all other settings. The 12x zoom is very nice.5. I paid $199.99 for this when it was on sale. Above what I was looking to pay but once I saw this camera and all its features, I had to have it.Accessories worth buying:1. Wasabi Power batteries (Wasabi Power Battery and Charger Kit for Panasonic Lumix DMW-BCG10, DMW-BCG10E, DMW-BCG10PP, DMC-ZR3, DMC-ZS5, DMC-ZS6, DMC-ZS7)2. Caselogic Case (Caselogic TBC-302 Ultra Compact Camera Case with Storage (Black))3. 8GB, 16GB, or 32GB SDHC cards4. Tripod

Reviews.Title: great camera for long clear zooms
Reviews.Author: kwh
Reviews.Content: could read a street sign over 2 1/2 blocks away after picture was taken very clearly.very good video,does ok on darker room shots & great in brighter light.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for Europe trip!
Reviews.Author: Jill K. Bell
Reviews.Content: Love this camera! Just back from Europe and got camera too late to learn and utilize all features but it was easy overallto use. GPS feature was great. I could find out where we were in our car with GPS turned on and pushingdisplay button---kind of fun! Extended zoom was wonderful especially at the top of Mt. Pilatus in Switzerlandand Oktoberfest. Little bit bigger than most of my previous point and shoots but did not cause any problemsat all toting it around. Not sure of rating hd video feature yet but I did decide to buy this camera because it not onlyhad a lot of zoom for still shots but also you could zoom in while taking video. In addition you can hear your video whenplaying back while you are still on trip.Only complaint---full manual is online and a lot of pages! There is a start-up small manual included in box but really very basic.Suggestion---get second battery especially if using GPS feature. Seemed to take a lot of juice to keep that going (but worth it).My photos are beautiful (great wide angle lens!) and using different scene modes helped quite a bit---was able to take pictures of fireworks at night.Highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: FInally!
Reviews.Author: Tom M.
Reviews.Content: Small backstory: I had a Panasonic DMC-LZ7 just prior to this which died in a bizarre carbonation homicide during a road trip. Anyway, on that trip I also tried the FH22 (pictures not sharp; touch screen was awful) and the ZR3 (pictures not sharp), both of which, as stated, were not as sharp as the LZ7. I wanted to stay with Panasonic because I think they're a good value. After those two cameras (and various prices) I figured I might as well go to the top of the line for point-and-shoots.This camera: It was a little more than I wanted to spend, but it was absolutely worth it. The only setting I changed was the sharpness (which is good at the factory setting of 0, but I raised to +2 for fun) and a couple other settings that were non picture related. You can customize just about every aspect of shooting your picture. Everything is pretty and already covered in the other reviews, so here's some of my notes:GPS: It does take about 30-60 seconds to find a signal if you haven't had one in a while. Also, while it has landmarks, it's not going to show you nearby restaurants or gas stations (or whatever) like a full GPS. It's pretty accurate on its coordinates and where the photo was taken. Also, if you're outdoors and take a few pictures with GPS, then go indoors and lose signal, it will still keep the last coordinate from outside unless you turn off the camera. For videos, AVCHD allows GPS coordinates to be embedded in the file. Outside of playback on camera, I have no idea how to extract coordinates from the video files.AVCHD: At full 720p, on an empty 2GB card, you can get about 15m 30s minutes of video. On the memory card, it makes a file structure so you can burn it directly to Blu-Ray, or you can just remove the .MTS files it creates if you just need the single file.Battery Life: Depending on your selection of GPS mode (I have mine set for GPS only when camera is on). My only test in this area is with video, I had it set to a lower setting (MotionJPEG, WVGA), 22mins of video and filled the card, deleted, and took more video and had 1/3 bars of battery left. Photos, I took about 200 in a row (testing) and it just dropped to 2/3 bars of battery.Size: In comparison to the LZ7 it's actually a little longer and heavier, but nothing to freak out about. For what it does, it's a great size. I will say originally I wanted an extra-slim camera but I didn't want to sacrifice picture quality or optical zoom.Dislikes:- Proprietary USB port/cable- Alleged blocking of 3rd party batteries by Panasonic (haven't needed a new battery, see other reviews)- Does not include photo software if you're a Mac user (personally, I didn't care).

Reviews.Title: Great features but does it have a flaw??
Reviews.Author: rockmeister
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera primarily because of its great optical zoom range and built in GPS.  I was preparing to go on a 17-day Mediterranian vacation/cruise.  I took about a dozen photos before the trip to familiarize myself with the camera.  All was well until the 7th day, ini Turkey, when suddenly the camera turned itself off after briefly displaying a message in a pop-up box.  It wouldn't then turn back on until I replaced the battery with a second Panasonic battery I bought with the camera.  When turning it back on then it displayed a messsage that 'Battery cannot be used' and turned itself off again.  After several tries and switching batteries back and forth I decided that the camera for some reason was now rejecting the Panasonic batteries.  I had read other product reviews that you had to be sure to buy the correct Panasonic battery or it would not work.  In the end I only had a working camera for less than half of the 'trip of a lifetime'.  Thanks Panasonic!After calling Panasonic warranty service they indicated all they could do was have me send the camera and all components that came with it to them and they would replace it with a refurbished one - trade a 30 day old camera in for one of unknown age and use - g-r-e-a-t!  Since I bought a SquareTrade extended warranty with the camera (on Amazon with the camera) I called them but they were no help.  They just defer to the manufacturer's warranty policy.I've read reviews of a few others having similar issues with the batteries so I do wonder if I will have the same problem again with the relacement camera, which I now have.  Should have bought a Canon or Nikon and forgotten about the GPS.  The GPS feature is nice to have BUT I have yet to find a photo processing site that can include the GPS information on prints, so if I want it on prints I have to print the photos myself on my computer using the included Panasonic software, a more expensive proposition since my Canon printer's ink is very expensive.If anyone reading this knows of such a site, please let me know.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: S. Leader
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera. Put it in the "auto everything" mode the just point and shoot. The image stabilization keeps everything in focus. Close-ups are in focus. Lighting is good, picture quality is great. This is the camera you want if you just like to take pictures without adjusting the settings. Have had this camera for about 30 days, and have not attempted to use a mode where I can adjust the settings. No real need to do that. Only items which need to be improved have nothing to do with taking pictures. Those would be the battery compartment, memory card/battery door, and the battery charger. I generally need to "play" with the position of the battery before I can close the compartment door. Also, the compartment door latch is weak. I think this will be the first thing to go (hopefully not for a few years). Using the battery charger is difficult. Most charges have a "red" indicator when charging, and green when finished. This one goes green when you first insert the battery. When the battery is charged the lamp is extinguished.

Reviews.Title: Macro pictures
Reviews.Author: D. Chin "Facilities"
Reviews.Content: The Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 takes great pictures for Macro photos.  I like to show off jewelry pictures of custom made rings.  The macro setting is exceptional especially with the zoom feature.  Macro pictures that produce clear pictures even when handheld and no tripod.This replaced my Canon camera A620 that took great shots but macro photography was lacking not good since it was only 4x optical zoom.  There is lots of room to learn more different styles of pictures with all the settings on this camera.The other great feature on this camera is that it is small and light as a point and shoot digital camera but has features that a DSLR has.Hard to find a camera case, but there are some out there that would fit.  Would recommend a case since the 3" display is your viewfinder.  It would be good to use a clear plastic screen to protect from scratches.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic could make it better...
Reviews.Author: Darko
Reviews.Content: Don't get me wrong it is a good camera. There are just little annoyances that could probably be avoided with better product design.Biggest issue is the battery - it is just way too short lived. I ended up by ordering another one...Having internal memory that can fit just 2 images is ridiculous. I can live with 10 or 20, but 2?GPS - I do not know - if battery is sucked without it in short time - what would be with living it on.iA is a kind a cool thing - but in iA mode you can not turn certain functions - like eco mode to turn off the screen - thus it want help you prolong battery life... well, I guess that you can switch between iA mode and user defined here and there...And final minus - in order to switch between camera mode and view mode - you need to do that with mechanical switch - another unnecessary flow - in older cameras that I have I could exit picture review mode clicking on shutter button.Pictures are nice - I like 12x. Camera is a decent size - it can fit in pocket of cargo pants or jacket easily. I took red - just for fun - and it is interesting to have some of electronics that is not a bit dull black and silver, at least gadgets vise. One of my main reasons to buy this camera were Leica lens - I hope they will match their name.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: R. Richardson "Home Theater Geek"
Reviews.Content: This camera packs a lot into a small package. My wife loves the zoom - but found out the greater the zoom the more the slightest movements are amplified. Image stabilization helps, but you need a steady hand. Her old Lumix 7 that we replaced had slow lag time and write times. This model is fast. It helps that we got a class 6 (fast) SDHC card. The multi shot mode takes about 20 (guessing) shots within a couple seconds. Great for sports. Camera memory allows fast multi-shots. The image quality is excellent. I'm very impressed. Haven't used the GPS feature. This is my wife's camera - she loves it... easy to use - turn it on take pictures. I was torn between this camera (ZS7) and Canon SX210 - both have wide angle and high zooms. I liked the zoom control on the Lumix better and Amazon had a $50 off special so got this one... no regrets. Battery life seems good. Bottom line is image quality and you won't be disappointed with this camera. Rivals some dSLRs.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Gayle Pierce
Reviews.Content: This camera is easy to use and the picture quality, both still and video is great.  Only thing I would have liked but most cameras nowadays don't have any more is a viewfinder for bright places.  The video is way better than my Flip HD camera.

Reviews.Title: This little camera has everything
Reviews.Author: Paul A. Henning
Reviews.Content: The Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 is a great point & shoot camera -- very easy to use, responsive, good anti-shake, HD video, 12x zoom, a bunch of scene modes, small, and the icing on the cake: GPS. Perfect travel camera!

Reviews.Title: Don't buy this camera
Reviews.Author: IZbraun
Reviews.Content: I would say that most of the reviews for this camera are written by people who have only had the camera for a short amount of time.  If I had written this review after a few months I would have given it an excellent rating too, but there's a major design flaw that doesn't make itself apparent until a lot of use.  It takes great pictures and has a great zoom.  The problem is that the little plastic door that covers the lens when the camera is turned off, or switched to play mode, is so close to the lens that it actually touches the lens when the camera is slipped into a camera case.  After a lot of use this eventually leaves scratches on the lens that get worse and worse to the point that all your pictures and videos have a blur in them.  By the time this becomes an apparent problem the camera will be out of warranty and Panasonic won't do anything to help you.

Reviews.Title: Wanted to love it...
Reviews.Author: David H. Rodgers
Reviews.Content: I really wanted to love this camera after reading and watching many reviews on it. It takes very good pictures although the highlights are often blown out more than they should be. My main gripe is the video and its format avchd lite, it is not easy to work with and you must purchase a video editing program if you want to do anything more than the ordinary stuff its included cd gives you. Unlike regular avchd formatted cameras the video will not open and play in most players. I also found the video to be too bright in the auto mode same as the pictures. Panasonic needs to keep working on this camera it is just not there yet. I returned mine and will go with something else.

Reviews.Title: High End Point/Shoot Camera That Keeps Up With The Big Boys!
Reviews.Author: J. Chae
Reviews.Content: As a semi professional photographer and an avid Nikon fan, I have a collection of dSLR and gear that goes along with it. With recurring day trips to local amusement parks, dinner occasions, birthday parties and so on... lugging my bulky dSLR and lenses becomes cumbersome and laboring. Although the image quality and the flexibility of my Nikon dSLR are second to none, I just got tired of hauling them around for minor occasion and events. Thus, I carefully researches (as I normally do with all my shopping)for a light weight point and shoot camera that can zoom (optically) adequately without loss of image quality, compact design, AVCHD capability, sharp focus and good low light performance. Also wanted a camera that would not break my bank and yet have the semi manual functionality. The GPS is added bonus, but personally don't use it much for my needs.After looking at entry level point and shoot (which are junk in my opinion) and some micro 4/3 cameras, I decided to settle in the middle of the two and get the Panasonic ZS7. After much reviews and comparison testings online, I purchased the ZS7 for its amazing video quality capabiltiy and sharpness. What even more rare is that the camera was manufactured in Japan (not China or other outsourced country). Not to be bias, but I tend to feel better about a product longevity and build quality when it's actually made in its mother country of origin.Here's my quick breakdown for the ZS7:Pros:----Affordable price range12 megapixel with high density pixel rating12x optical zoom with 3x added digital = 15x total zoomMinimal motor noise for zoom (good for video recording)Full time autofocus for video even when zoomingGreat low light shooting capability and even long shutter option in manual modeManual function option like dSLR  (Aperture, Shutter and Manual modes)Compact design and aluminum casing all aroundNice bright 3" LCDIntuitive menu structureLeica LensWith enough SD card size, can become camcorder replacementAVCHD and rolling JPG option for Video (shoots 720p) looks amazing on 1080p TV with HDMIHDMI output using mini HDMI portGPS featureMade In JapanCons:-----Short Battery life when video is used oftenLCD screen seems to scratch easily (investment in protective pouch/bag mandatory)No bag/case providedBattery must be charged via charging base (via socket)CD comes with horrible photo editing softwareNo video editing software for AVCHD formatOverall a great camera that is hard to beat in terms of price, quality, features and performance. Just order a second or possibly even 3rd battery if you are planning to take lot of pictures within the day with no access to charger.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, but buy it at Costco
Reviews.Author: Susan
Reviews.Content: I agree with all the other positive comments.  But....  buy it at Costco for $199 and you also get a carrying case and a 2mg SD memory card, plus you get an additioanl 2 yr warranty.  Amazon used to represent the best price, but now you just can't count on them and you need to shop around.

Reviews.Title: Don't let the "out of the box" picture quality fool you
Reviews.Author: Robert Shaw "Life is TOO short to listen to b...
Reviews.Content: I had a dmc zs3 camera for a few years and loved it.It went everywhere I did and worked well in virtually any setting.It spent 2 weeks going down the Colorado river, skiing trips, 10 degree nights in the desert, HD video taping on the dash of the truck while 4-wheeling, concerts, parties, you name it...and it worked great, until it died when the focus gear stripped out (fixable I hear, parts available on ebay).Well, I spent hours and hours reading reviews for a replacement camera that could replace my mighty little zs3 knowing that there was fierce competition in the under $300 category and ended up getting the zs7 simply because I already had the extra batteries, cables and waterproof Pelican case that would fit it.And I got it despite what some reviews said about the supposed diminished photo quality from the zs3 model.Well, it's only worse than the zs3 if you don't tinker with the Noise, Contrast, Sharpness and Saturation settings.Once you tinker with them a little the pictures are outstanding for a pocket camera.You will never go back to a 35mm lense once you see you can get a whole room in one shot with its 25mm wide angle Leica lense.The flash is enough to light up a living room and the auto focus features ensure subjects are usually in focus.The HD video is perfect for recording everything from nature scenes to rock concerts and the stereo sound quality is good enough to play on your stereo and not wince.Battery life is pretty good for a camera that does so many automatic things like IR and continuous autofocus.AVCHD is very good for putting hours of quality HD video on a 16GB SDHC card.....but be sure to get a Class 6 or higher card or you will have buffer issues writing at the HD video speed.There are MANY menu settings as this camera does about everything a picky amateur photographer could want IF you just bother to mess with the settings until you find what you like.I rarely use the Intelligent Auto mode as the Program, Apeture priority, Shutter priority and manual modes prove superior.Seeing as my passport arrived a few days ago I will not hesitate for a moment to put this in a backpack (inside its Pelican case, along with the waterproof Olympus as a backup) and go to another country for a week with it being sure it will perform well.Spend the extra $49 for the Square Deal 3 year unlimited warranty as you will surely be depressed if anything happens to this camera and leaves you without.....It's THAT good........

Reviews.Title: The not so perfect Camera for the Field!
Reviews.Author: Brad F. Cooper
Reviews.Content: Being a field biologist and an armature nature photographer I thought this camera would be great because...1) Megazoom, Leica lens2) Compact sizeMy previous camera was a Panasonic FZ5 (Awesome camera for my needs) which replaced the Nikon 4300.Last fall (2009) my FZ5 finally failed and it would cost more money than it was worth to fix it. So I started the search for a replacement. If I was smart I would have just replaced it with another FZ series camera and be done with it. However, I wanted a camera that was smaller and still had the same features as my FZ5. After months of research and resizing that the 2010 field season was coming up I needed to make a decision. So I chose the Panasonic DMC-TZ10/ZS7, because of its small size and megazoom, Leica lens. Some of the reviews complained about the battery life, the GPS, and video features this camera provided. I however, did not care about the GPS and video functions since that's what the Trimble/Garmin are for. As for batteries, I always carry 2-3 extra batteries with me because when I am in the field I have no power sources for days on end. I basically wanted a camera that is small but still offered the megazoom feature and good image quality.In the beginning the camera worked flawlessly. After 2 months of ownership and being very careful with it then lens/focusing system failed. I would get an error and the lens would not focus or extend in and out of the camera body. I turned off the camera and removed/replaced the battery and the lens barrel still did not retract.Panasonic replaced the camera since it was under warranty.The replacement worked for only 1 month before it also failed in the exact same manner. Being Irate with the lens failure for a second time on the DMC-TZ10/ZS7 and then on another Panasonic camera the DMC-FH5 I am giving up on Panasonic's smaller camera. For the rest of the field season I had to use my personal Canon G11 which I absolutely love it just does not have the supper zoom feature.I am giving the DMC-TZ10/ZS7 a 3 star rating because of the poor workmanship and quality of the lens barrel. The Leica lens (glass) is fantastic as is the easy use of the camera and it's size. The camera is good for certain occasions but not for taking outside and hiking around the woods and desert or in general the great outdoors for long periods of time.Overall not a bad camera, but there are so many others out there you can do better.

Reviews.Title: Awesome specs but the results not as good as Nikon's S8100
Reviews.Author: Robert S.
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as an upgrade to my older Panasonic Lumix. I wanted the HD movie capability. That might have been it. But my father suggested I look at just released Nikon S8100.I compared both cameras side by side for about 3 weeks. In short, Panasonic is a great contender but the Panasonic's ZS7's picture is NOT natural (it is over processed). The colors are slightly off and the edges are jagged (example: cat's fur looks unnatural). This is not a problem with Nikon S8100.This Panasonic has great selling points (over and beyond Nikon S8100): 1) awesome Leica lens, 2) fast and superb focus at any zoom, 3) aggressive use of flash, 4) great (hand) ergonomics. As a result it is bound to always take good pictures.The Nikon S8100 is better in practice, however. 1) It can take awesome naturally looking pictures. 2) It is easier to use (for my girlfriend). 3) Night photos are way, way better than anything remotely possible on the Panasonic (probably including other point and shoot cameras, too).I kept Nikon S8100.

Reviews.Title: Lumix DMC-ZS7: Great Buy!
Reviews.Author: Hawkeye
Reviews.Content: The ZS7 is a pretty good camera for a point-and-shoot. I agree with most of the positive reviews this camera has earned. I was looking for a camera that could easily take video as well as stills without compromising on the quality of either. The ZS7 delivers on both counts. Stills are crystal clear and sharp. Try out the different scene modes and you will find one that is appropriate for the situation in hand. The video is true HD and can stand up to the resolution even if viewed on a 50" or larger HDTV if you use the HDMI interface. Too bad this cable is not included. A word of caution: you need to buy a mini-HDMI to HDMI for this camera. One drawback of this camera is that if you are shooting a video you cannot simultaneously take stills. There is a lag time between switching from the video mode to the still mode (a sliding switch). Contrary to some concerns about using the zoom while in video mode, I can report that I was very happy with the results. Zooming in and out while in video mode did not introduce any motor noise in my video. I wish the software supplied was compatible with my Mac G4. But there are other software out there which can be used to download the HD video to the Mac. The GPS function of the camera was not all that it is cracked up to be. It still showed me to be in a state that was over a 1000 miles away! Just turn off the GPS if you don't really need it and you will save a lot on battery juice! For all of those wanting to buy a camera that can give you the dual functionality of shooting video and stills, I recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Excellent optics and picture quality, but poor sensitivity in the dark
Reviews.Author: Rouslan Dimitrov
Reviews.Content: I've owned my dark blue ZS7 for 2 months and overall it is great - stylish and sturdy body, great optics and electronics, but not so good sensor.+ Image stabilization works really well. Even at 12x zoom pictures are sharp+ Relatively wide-angle+ Compact size for such optics+ Great build quality+ GPS and geo-tagging+ Lots of options exposed in manual mode+ Flash strength is decreased if focused on near objects+ Stereo mics+ HD video recording+ Various wide-angle resolutions- Poor sensitivity in the dark. On candle light, pictures are noisy and washed-out.- GPS drains the battery a bit in off mode (can be completely disabled from the menu, but takes a few minutes to update your location)- Does not charge from USB (even drains the battery when transferring photos).Overall, for a camera I recommend it. After buying it, though, I realized that for 80% of the photos I take, it was not much of an upgrade from my phone which has an excellent camera (LG Renoir, 8MP).If you do casual point and shoot, and you prefer not to carry an extra gadget, spend the money on a good phone.If you are an amateur photographer and don't want to carry a bulky SLR, the ZS7 will get you close.

Reviews.Title: Comparison with Canon S3
Reviews.Author: Michael K. Gaston "Early Adaptor"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 to replace my Canon Powershot S3, which I had irreparably damaged (dropped onto pavement - ouch!)  I had been quite pleased with my Canon.  I miss it!We also have a single lens Nikon with great lenses - the DMC-Zs7 (as was the Powershot S3) is a back-up, and an alternative when we don't want to haul the Nikon around.  It fits this purpose well.  Photos are very good, just not at the level of a single lens.The DMC-ZS7 is an improvement on my older Canon point and shoot in several areas.The DMC-ZS7 has much better zoom - the wide angle end of the zoom works much better for landscape than the Canon, and and it has a greater zoom (Canon was 10x Panasonic is 12x).  The 12x zoom is very adequate for me - other camera's in this price category can go up to 18x but don't have as good a wide angle.  I personally would go with the wide angle rather than the extra "zoom."  You might want the 18X if your primary usage would be shooting wildlife at a distance - particularly birds.  That said, the lack of a viewfinder makes this camera more difficult to use for birding - I find it hard to quickly "find" small wildlife on the LCD at maximum zoom.I miss my viewfinder on the Canon.  It had both the viewfinder and the view screen.  The Panasonic has a better 3 inch view screen, but no viewfinder.  I guess I'm old fashioned that way.  I'll get used to it (I hope).The Panasonic is much smaller - much easier to carry.  It's impressive that you have that they can fit that zoom into that small a camera.The Panasonic really goes through it's battery if you have the GPS active.  I personally don't think the GPS adds much.  It mostly identifies the city/state, but unless you are shooting at a major tourist site, it doesn't narrow the photo to the specific site.  You are going to get city/state and latitude/longitude.  I don't find that to be particularly useful.  I'll probably leave it turned off.  Sounds great, but I wouldn't make a purchase decision between cameras to get the GPS feature.The Canon used standard batteries.  That was great if you were traveling in Europe and didn't want to bother with power adapters for a battery charger.  I've had to charge the Panasonic batteries more often than I anticipated, even with GPS off.  You definitely will need to have an extra, charged battery on hand.The camera pauses after each shot to "preview" the last shot.  I turned that off in the menu, but I still get a slight, irritating pause.  (Perhaps I don't have the setting correct - but I think I do.)The menu system is intuitive.  I mostly use automatic and scene-panoramic stitch.  The stitch works well, it includes an overlay image that helps you line up multiple photos to stitch together.  It is hard to see the overlay image in bright light, but I do like that feature.  The burst mode works much better than the burst mode in my old Canon - the photos come out quite clear with good resolution.  I also tried the scene-underwater to shoot some small fish in a stream - I was very impressed with the results.One glitch on this camera is that if you rotate the camera to get a "tall" shot instead of a "wide" shot, the LCD is darker.  You'll need to take off your sunglasses to frame your photo.  Strange.The camera takes great photos - slightly better photos than my old Canon - which also took great photos.  Not so much better to justify buying a new camera (unless you break your old one :))I don't care much for the Panasonic software that's included.  For instance, I don't see a setting that allows you to automatically delete photos from the camera after download.  Also - my Canon and Nikon software have more functionality for viewing, quick editing and renaming.  I think I'll continue to use my old software unless I'm stitching.  As far as I can tell, the Canon software stitches the Panasonic photos just fine, so I may just continue to use the Canon software for all downloads.You will need to buy an extra battery ($30 or so), a camera case (a cheap one costs around $10 after shipping), and a plastic cover for the LCD screen ($5 or so), and a memory chip.  (The internal memory is much too small for any vacation.)I'm happy with the purchase - I paid around $280.This was a good buy.  I recommend the ZS7 for anyone who wants a good wide angle and good but not the best zoom, especially if you can get the camera for around $280 (or less).  If you have to pay the $350 suggested price, I would shop around.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: AZ Desert Rat "movie buff"
Reviews.Content: I wanted this Camera for it's wide angle lens and zoom.  It does not disappoint in those respects. My father always talked of how wonderful Leica lenses were so that's a bonus.  However, the best part is, this camera works seemlessly with my MacBook Pro.  Iphoto, Imovies and IDvd work with it like they made the camera for them.  I see other reviewers are saying how bad the software is for PCs.  Well Apple users rejoice.  I love the way this camera interacts with my Mac laptop.
