The movies are spectacular and so easy to edit with IMovie.I did not want the blue model but Amazon had a sale with an extra $50 off the blue camera, you could not beat the price.  I see this camera selling at the local big box store for $150 more than I paid so I'm happy.  Highly recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great W I D E angle Hi Def Camcorder - er - Camera (Made in Japan too)
Reviews.Author: B. Roy "RoyTech"
Reviews.Content: I have a bagful of camera's by now and one of them is the earlier iteration to this camera - the  TZ-3. Did not quite like its color rendering and that camera itself has now stopped working (hangs after taking a couple of pics). I wasn't sure if I should buy its newer cousin but some of its features were in line with what I wanted. Turns out - Panasonic has made great strides in the intervening years. For one thing - color is vastly improved compared to earlier models.Now that I've used it for a while -1) Its truly a great shirt pocket size, wide angle, Hi Def camcorder. Dedicated HD camcorders don't come with a wide angle lens and all they let you capture at your kids b'day is the cake and two people on either side. With this camcorder - you can capture the crowd and when you play it back big screen, it looks spectacular with true colors and high resolution. With the huge resolution increase possible with HD video, you also need a wide angle lens to do it justice.2) It can zoom while taking video - all the way to 12X optical and to 16X with not much perceptible loss of resolution. The zoom is silent and does not grate into your sound (I don't note it). Focus is maintained rock steady through zooming. Zooming is slow, but that can be a good thing - most people zoom too much and fast in home video's - making home video's un-watchable.3) Someone mentioned two zooming speeds. Really? I see only one zooming speed. Not like a camcorder where zooming speed can be varied by pressing more or less on the zooming lever. Takes me about 10 seconds to go from 1 to 16X - so its a bit slow.4) Sound is good (stereo mike and dolby digital recording). Way way better than any other camera based sound I have used so far. The mikes are on top and prone to get blocked with my fingers now and then. Wish they were in front.5) There are 3 selectable bit rates - I use the highest one and later join and recompress the videos with the free DIVX converter to MKV. I don't note any stutter or jitter in my video's.6) With approx 12MB left in my card, the camera can take one and half hrs of video at highest bit rates, 2 hrs at medium and 3 hrs at the lowest setting. Thats plenty long. I use a class 4 card and works fine (AVCHD compression).7) Low light performance w/o zoom is also tolerable. If you also zoom in low light, too little light reaches the sensor for  decent images.  By low light - I mean a dimly lit room. With normal lighting, the video's look fine.8) Image stabilization is very good. I can even walk with the camera and take watchable video's.9) Face detection works when taking video's - perfectly exposed faces in a backlit environment.10) The batteries don't last very long when taking video's (haven't calculated how long). The batteries are electronically locked - so not any aftermarket spare will work. However - this one works fine (I just bought it) and the battery came fully charged -http://www.amazon.com/Power2000-Replacement-1200mAh-Lithium-Panasonic/dp/B002VJ1FDE/ref=sr_1_5?s=electronics&ie;=UTF8&qid;=1280437856&sr;=1-511) Way way better than a Flip HD camcorder in every way. I am really puzzled why people buy Flips anymore.Other notes -1) Shape and size are perfect. You really want a rectangular box and not some crazy rounded shape like some of the Canon's (like SD 940 - which  I own). Box is the only shape that will stand stable on its edge when you are trying to take a self timer shot. Fits fine in a shirtpocket with a cloth case on it.2) Low light with zoom can make for really noisy pics (visible when you see them at 100%). (I mostly use my SLR for "in-home" pics)3) Lens is really sharp. I can note the diff with SD940 (Canon).4) Color is good.5) GPS is essential and works well. Only way to remember where pics were taken 10 years from now. I leave it on at all times.6) Made in Japan (not China)7)Does not have a standard USB port - so you need to keep the special cable handy. Its not as big a con anymore since I rarely connect a camera to a computer.8) Panasonic does give you firmware updates to improve the performance of the camera after you've bought it. I just updated mine from 1.0 to 1.1.9) The viewing screen is very good , antireflective coated and visible in bright sunlight.10) Flash pics are much better exposed than my Canon SD94011) I hope it lasts - unlike my TZ-3.12) Ergonomics, button arrangement and screen information is excellent. Nice metal throught I used to not like the one press video function, but with a kid in the house, I think its the way to go. There's lots more one can write on this camera but I need to keep this review short. I'll be happy to answer  specific questions anyone might have.

Reviews.Title: Lumix DMC-ZS7
Reviews.Author: Stanley Z Greenspan
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for a trip to Israel. My other camera is a DSLR and I didn't want to carry the larger camera and lenses on this trip.The DMC-ZS7 is my second Lumix camera, and I was very happy with the first one. The DMC-ZS7 is a great camera with a really fine lens on it and excellent controls and software. The only failing is the GPS's thirst for battery power. It sucks through the electrons at a prodigiuos rate, and if the GPS is left in the ON position, it will drain the battery in about 3 days, even when the camera is off. If left in the Aircraft mode, the battery lasts quite a bit longer.Overall, an excellent camera, the GPS is cool but needs to be used with care. A second battery is essential.

Reviews.Title: Buy this for the "burst" feature
Reviews.Author: billwilloughby
Reviews.Content: The main advantage of this camera to the competition is the "burst" feature--the ability to take a lot of pictures with one click of the button.  So far as I can tell, none of the competition has anything like as fast, (read: useful) feature. This is huge. You have them say "cheese" and squeeze off six pictures in the high-speed mode.  One of them is bound to be good. Brute force brought to home photography.  Take this camera to your kid's little league game and squeeze the shutter when he bats.  At the end of the game you will have one or two "once in a lifetime" photos that would usually take an entire season of little league photography to match.  As far as I can tell, the pictures are better than competing Fujifilm model, not as good as competing Canon (P90).  Lumix is $[...] bucks or so cheaper than either.A few "Musts"1.  Buy the extra battery.  I don't know if they really have this anti-competitive software program that rigs the camera to not work with certain batteries, or not.  I do know that a spare battery can be bought cheaply with the original camera.  You can easily burn through a battery (rechargeable) through a day of hard shooting.2.  Turn off the fake shutter noise. Never turn it back on. Your subjects will be about 10X more tolerant of your "burst" picture taking without the noise.3.  Get a decent, high capacity, fast card.  I got a 133X Lexar 16GB for about $65. SanDisk 16GB Extreme - SDHC Class 10 High Performance memory card (SDSDX3-016G-P31, Retail Packaging) - NEW 30MB/s version If its not a high speed card, it can't use the burst function very well. (although I think my 133X card was probably overkill). This is a little tricky.  The industry standard is to rate cards by class, with class 10 being the highest.  Oddly, Sandisk, one of the biggest manufacturers prefers to market their high speed disks as "133X" I suppose to avoid a licensing fee for use of the term "Class 10"  So you have to search for both 133X and Class 6 or Class 10 to see what is available.The camera has an array of preset settings. Some are actually useful. I like "happy" (Kodachrome-like color saturation) and "soft-skin" portrait which really does give you good portraits.  The "transform" feature makes you look thinner!  It has two settings: Subtly slimming and "fun-house mirror"The wide-angle 25 mm equivalent lens is way more useful than a telephoto in real life.The good people at Square Trade after-market warranty say that the Panasonics are definitely more reliable than the point-and-shoot competition, which is like being the one-eyed man in the land of the blind. It does seem pretty sturdy, though.The bad:  Yeah, the flash is a little weak.  I am having some trouble programming the "custom" settings to take good pictures.  Not all features are combinable into one custom setting, so far as I can tell.  Just some.  The GPS is kinda stupid.  I understand the S57 doesn't have it.  I don't like the price, although its highly competitve in its class.  All in, its over $[...] bucks.  I can't get over that for a point and shoot camera.  At the same time, the longer I own this camera the more I think it was a good deal.Overall: Perfect camera for a young, active family, and travelers. Doting grandparents looking for a nice gift that pays dividends in grandchild pictures, take note.

Reviews.Title: Best All Around Long Zoom Compact in Past 5 Years
Reviews.Author: Sam Bravern
Reviews.Content: ZS7 is my 8th digital camera.  I get a new one every 18-24 months. I've always bought compact or ultra-compact.  Owned Canon, Panasonic, and Olympus. I've always researched my purchases extensively. Done test shot comparisons and balanced pixel level analysis with overall features, ergonomics, and ease of use. The ZS7 is still the all around best compact long zoom out there, for my needs.  Here's a breakdown what I like about it and why I didn't buy some of the other popular latest models:1) Image Quality: Excellent white balance, color accuracy, and most importantly best balance between noise reduction and detail preservation.  All newer models of this camera gradually went downhill as far as increasing noise reduction while decreasing preservation of detail.  If you do post-editing noise removal, you can always 'backout' if you do too much.  But this is not possible if the camera is already doing too much (for your preference) in-camera.  Post-processing noise reduction is only needed on this camera starting at ISO 400 or 800 depending on your print size.2) Easy to use with flexibility for different user types.  Fairly quick start-up and focusing.  Casual users can put it in iA (Intelligent Auto) and not mess with settings and it takes great photos in a variety of situations.  Tons of flexibility for Advanced Users with Aperture/Shutter Speed/and ISO priority available.3) Indoor Flash: Doesn't have the annoying pop-up flash yet still takes good, well-exposed/balanced indoor flash photos.4) Good ergonomics5) Video: Although it's 720P and not 1080, 720 is more than adequate for home movies.  1080 is only really beneficial if you are trying to take video for a semi-professional application where video will be displayed via projector or large screen (IMHO).  More importantly, you can zoom while taking video and it focuses well while you do it and you don't hear the zoom motor in the video like you do on so many other cameras.This camera would be perfect if it had a) a faster burst mode, b) high-speed/slo-mo video, and c) HDR (I think HDR is the best new feature to come along in the past few years by far)I've actually bought two of these.  The first I bought 6 mos. ago after researching all latest models, but lost it on a trip.  I re-did all my research of all the latest cameras just now and still went with another ZS7.  Here's why:Canon SX230 - This is the closest runner up.  About the same image quality (good detail but a little more lens distortion), easy to use and takes reliably good shots.  Dealbreaker on this one was only 28mm wide and pop-up flash.  If you don't want super wide lens, and are okay with awkward pop-up flash, this is the only camera I would choose currently over the ZS7.  I think most average users would be better off with the smaller Elph 310 without the pop-up flash which has excellent image quality for the size of the camera.Nikon Coolpix 8100/9100 - These Nikons are prone to problems/mechanical failures (see reviews).  Nikon enthusiasts have not been happy with them.  Not willing to take the chance on them.Sony HX7V/HX9V - Dealbreaker for me on these is too much noise reduction (softer photos) and slow operation.  Otherwise this is a VERY good camera all around.  I wish I had the HDR this camera has on the ZS7.  Sony's are expensive though and I've found in the past even with faster cameras, that I miss shots and video opportunities sometimes waiting for the camera to start up or switch modes.  The slowness is the Achilles heel of this camera.  And those picky about image quality will not like the aggressive noise reduction.  This would be my runner up to the SX230 though and if you can get past the slowness and higher price, this may be the best choice for the casual point-and-shoot user that wants a powerful camera with lots of features and good low light without flash performance.  I would have gone with an HX9V if it was faster with a little less noise reduction, this would easily be the hands down winner for me.It ceases to amaze me that it is so difficult for manufacturers to actually make real improvements to cameras in subsequent models in the area of image quality, ergonomics, and reliability.  Instead they just keep packing on sensors with more megapixels that offer no image quality improvement or even introduce more noise, only for marketing purposes.  GPS to me is gimmick and just an extra drain on the battery (I turn it off on the ZS7.)  Who can't remember where they took their photos?

Reviews.Title: Very Nice Camera!
Reviews.Author: SU Fan
Reviews.Content: I've had this little gem for a few months now and I have to tell all, I am not disappointed. The ZS7 is everything I had hoped it to be and more. It's small and fits nicely into shirt & pant pockets, has mostly metal quality construction and feels solid; the zoom feature is great, smooth and quiet and works in movie mode but more than anything, IT TAKES GREAT QUALITY PICTURES IN AUTO MODE and very nice 720P movies. Funny, I almost didn't purchase this camera because a lot of reviewers on this and other sites say it "takes good pictures." I don't know what people expect from this camera but either the word Good has to be redefined by Webster's Dictionary people or camera reviewers are the harshest on the planet. To me "good means average, this camera takes EXCELLENT pictures in daylight/sunlight conditions and very decent pictures in low light. The colors are very natural on auto default settings. There is a scene mode for warmer colors though if you want them. Focusing is fast and accurate and stabilization is excellent. At the price point I purchased this camera at, it was a steal.  Folks, this is not a $2500.00 SLR. This is a quality built point and shoot camera that is meant to be sold for a few hundred dollars. For the money, this is an excellent performing product.Full manual mode is available and if you have the desire to be creative you can be but just don't blame the camera if you don't get the settings right.  I use manual mode but mostly rely on the Auto Mode. The back screen is very easy on the eyes with its high pixel count, though I suspect very bright sunshine might or could be an issue. The menus are intuitive. And, I have to admit .... I haven't read the "how to use" guide for the camera as I just took it out of the box and started shooting! Regarding battery life: no problems with short life so far but purchased an extra battery anyway. Better safe than sorry.In closing, I should mention that my previous "point & shoots" were all "top rated for picture taking" Canons. In my eyes, there is no comparison. The ZS7 is tops in quality across the board. It's not that the Canons were bad, heck at the time I thought they were great but this "gem" is that much better.  Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Great quality pictures, simple to use.Good buy!
Reviews.Author: brk
Reviews.Content: Not much else to be said beyond the title, really. It's simple to use, delivers excellent quality pictures and can only be faulted for a slight (but tolerable) shutter lag. I'd highly recommend this compact camera to any casual user.

Reviews.Title: Great Performance
Reviews.Author: D. Myers
Reviews.Content: This is a fantastic camera.  I have used it traveling and having the GPS makes it great to review your trips with your location.  Has all the extra features you need for customized shots or the auto settings make it easy for most shots.  Great zoom and with the new one that is out with 14.1 mp and a 16x zoom it should be very impressive. You will not be dissapointed.

Reviews.Title: High quality Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: Dutch Oven Guy
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for times when a full size DSLR is too much weight to carry.  I will not repeat the positive comments made by previous reviews.  The GPS does take a bit of time to lock on so best to get the camera outside well in advance of taking crucial shots.  I did not find battery drain to be significantly increased by having the GPS on all the time.  I have a bad habit of reviewing images on the camera.  This drains the battery far more than did the GPS. During a full day of shooting and reviewing I was able to completely drain a battery, so the spare was necessary.The zoom and stabilization are quite good.  Auto-focus does take a bit of time, so pre-focusing is helpful when a quick shot is required.This camera went up past the Arctic Circle to the farthest northern point in Europe with no problems. In gloomy lighting it tended to brighten up the scene somewhat in the iA mode - easy to correct in an image editor back home.I highly recommend this camera as a lightweight companion.  Its replacement, TS-10, is presently very expensive in comparison.

Reviews.Title: The Camera I've Been Looking For!
Reviews.Author: W. Mueller "b1bill"
Reviews.Content: Wow!  Our family just took a vacation and had a chance to take over 1500 pictures with this camera.  We also took several pictures at my son's track meet.  I'm so please with the results!I wanted an easily carried, simple use, camera that takes great pictures of people and landscapes both indoors and out.  I also need a high 12.1 MP because I like to crop pictures, image stabilization to compensate for movement, and a high 12X optical zoom so I can nice pictures from a distance.  We've also use the "burst" feature to take several quick succession pictures of my son running fast.  The Leica DC Vario-Elmar lens is great.The things that were not important to us are software and GPS feature.  We use Apple's iPhoto on our MAC to download the pictures and it works great.  We kept the GPS turned off.  We haven't used the video recording feature much, but have been pleased with it so far.This is a solid, great performing "point and shoot" camera that has some advanced features for folks who know how to use them.  The battery life is decent.  We could get a day and a half of heavy use out of it (with GPS feature turned off).We paired our camera with the following items purchased on Amazon:- 2 Transcend 8 GB Class 6 SDHC Flash Memory Cards ($13.63 each) - [...]- A Targus Digital Camera Neck Strap ($4.00) - [...]- A GGS Optical Glass LCD Screen Protector 3" for Digital Cameras ($4.45) Perfect Fit!!!- [...]- A Caselogic TBC-302 Ultra Compact Camera Case with Storage ($7.24) A Little Tight - [...]Bottom line:  I've gotten some disappointing cameras in the past and shopped around for a better camera.  This camera is the best I've ever owned.  We paid $199, but I would have paid much more for such a great find!!

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera..
Reviews.Author: GreatGains
Reviews.Content: I bought a Red ZS7 in March for my holidays and my feedback is that it satisfies all the requirements. I did not have to carry the camcorder this time, as the video recording was good.One day at the beach, I was taking the picture of the early morning scenery, and suddenly a wave splashed across me and also across the lens. Suddenly I tried to sponge out the water from the camera..and after some time, I found that the camera lens cover is not opening or closing completely.. I was wooried and rushed to hotel room and used a hair drier to blow hot air so that excess water is evaporated from the lens cover, and after few minutes, the camera worked perfectly fine.Even with 1000 photos of 12M setting, and videos of aprox 1hr, my 16GB card was having spare space in it.. the Videos were very clear but the image stabilisation is below expectation.I had purchased additional spare batteries from Amazon, which comes really handy during the day, and I found that Original LUMIX battery goes out after half a day with GPS ONStill learning to cut still shots from the videos, but I think the PhotoFunStudio 5.1 does not support this. Mainly used PhotoFunStudio for automatic retouch function to lighten the still pictures.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Realtor' Choice
Reviews.Author: Jimi
Reviews.Content: As a realtor, I have been more than pleased with this camera.  This camera does a fanastic job of interior pics of each room because of the wide angle lens.  I know of others' experience with claimed wide angle.  The Pansonic ZS7 Lumix digital camera is easy to use and works perfect for a realtor.I was very pleased with Amazon's no hassel ordeering and prompt shipment .  Jimi G

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: cckat
Reviews.Content: This is my second camera, I had to replace my Canon Powershot that I had for a few years. This camera was the perfect choice for the price and good replacement. It has an amazing zoom, my pictures are crisp and the color is on point, the GPS is definately a plus. There are many options so it might take sometime to get used to. Overall very good camera! :D

Reviews.Title: Big Bang for the Buck!!!
Reviews.Author: mb4now
Reviews.Content: Been researching cameras for a couple of weeks.Did alot of comparing and reviews of over a hundred camreas. Very impressed with the performance so far..Not much internal memory but on a 0.3m setting of 640x480 could get 66 pics..I have had it less than a week so far.Amazing zoom and pics so far.Got a 16gb sdhc card in now and can get 3074 pics @ 12megapixal setting.At lowest setting can get 69,416 pics. It`s very easy to navigate.Many cool features like all the scene selections to choose from, plus all kinds of both custom and manual settings for the more advanced users. Quick start up times for those spur of the moment shots. Buttons tho are a bit smaller than i care for but dosen`t affect performance, that`s the only con i have so far. Do recommend extra batteries and car charger,plus screen protector.Built very well.Nothing cheap feeling about it.Has really good reviews and a great camera for the money.I like going camping and hiking and wanted something easy to carry but with a higher zoom,12 megapixal  and really good pic quality and this hits the nail on the head.Took some good sunset photos already and some nice outdoor pics. IA setting does really well both indoors and out.Has a great manual online you can download with the software that has both manual and photofunstudio 5.1 on it..Have had issues with photofun studio 5.1 software sent with it so I`m just using Adobe photo shop which works just fine.There`s plenty of free software online that can do same do just as good or better so don`t let that hinder any decision.Cnet and PCworld are just a few sites to check on for product tests and reviews. Would def. recommend to anyone this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: alexrum
Reviews.Content: I had a earlier version of this camera and loved it. this one seems to be even better.Video quality is great, I don't think I will be buying camcorders any more,; camera can zoom in/out during the recording. Recording at night are also surprisingly good.Picture quality is good too, i like it even better than those of Canon models.One word of caution, if you were to buy a replacement battery be aware that the camera will refuse most of the batteries as it looks for a special chip in it. For the same reason upgrading firmware in the camera is a shot in the dark. Took a star away for that.

Reviews.Title: Fabulous Little Workhorse
Reviews.Author: justsayhey55
Reviews.Content: I purchased my first Lumix in 2007 for a medical mission to Peru, then took it to Uganda.  I've since purchased two more for family.  What a little workhorse.  I'ts been tumbled in the back on trucks, ground in the dirt (accidently), and still takes fabulous pictures.  This new model is even nicer, with better zoom and the wide angle seems to be better.  Last took this model to SE Asia and it handled the humidity just fine.  Also, rarely get red-eye.  Best buy for a point-and-shoot.  Also took pretty good videos.

Reviews.Title: Performs as expected
Reviews.Author: Bill
Reviews.Content: This camera lives up to other five star reviews in performance and on the key parameters prompting my purchase - small size, great pics, and near super zoom.  I also own an Olympus super zoom which is cumbersome to use because of its size and weight.  That is, the larger camera has to be unpacked and packed again while hiking, biking or boating which often prevents or deters the taking of pictures on these outings.  Add a pair binoculars and these two items can weight down a pack otherwise loaded with water bottles and other trail items.  The little Panasonic can be comfortably worn on the belt or lashed to one's backpack (little carry bag not included) or even simply carried in your jacket or pant pocket. Very nice.  Now I'm more likely to take pictures while on the trail.  The larger camera may take better pics, but what's the point if its a hassle?  Having the ZS7 gives me the flexibility to carry light and shoot quickly.  Nice camera, I'm glad I bought it.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix ZS7 Photography Made Easy
Reviews.Author: Joe B.
Reviews.Content: I used the camera at my niece's wedding.  I was amazed that a camera this small could take such amazing photos.  No need to worry about redeye in the pictures, just put it on automatic, then just point and shoot.  The camera does most of the work.  I wholeheartedly recommend this product.  The ease with which it takes pictures is worth the price.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Stephen E. Franklin
Reviews.Content: This camera is really impressive. It takes beautiful, sharp, bright photos with very good detail and contrast. After two weeks and 600 photos, I do recommend it. One area I would recommend improving: the battery.I found out after buying this camera that it is actually a rebadged LEICA V-LUX 20. Of course you can  see the Leica nameplate on the lens of the Lumix and the golden "L" on the front lower right hand of the steel body.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic camera
Reviews.Author: geno
Reviews.Content: Second panasonic camera of this type I have purchased because the first one was lost. This camera is just as good as the first takes great photos and is easy to use. I compare the quality of the images to my Canon 50D. The reason I bought it was because I wanted a small camera with a good zoom that would focus quickly to avoid that lag that so many point and shoots have. Totally happy with my purchase and would do it again without a doubt.

Reviews.Title: This is my favorite camera to date.
Reviews.Author: L. Lemmond
Reviews.Content: I got this camera about a week ago and couldn't be more pleased.  The photo and video quality are both excellent.  The automatic features are easy to use right out of the box and if you do some reading you can really put some of the other features of this camera to good use too.  In just this past week I have taken some of the best pictures I have in a long time.  I have dabbled in photography on and off my whole life so I love this camera and all the features and freedom it gives you for a point and shoot.  If you are looking for a camera that you are going to put in automatic mode and not explore any further you will get good photos in most situations but you will probably be buying more camera than you need.  If you like to tinker with some manual modes and different settings though you will not be disappointed with this camera.  The only drawbacks are minor ones in my opinion.  It is not the greatest camera out there for low light but it is not awful either.  There is a little noise on video playback when you zoom while recording videos.  It's not loud but it's there.  Other than that to me this camera is perfect.  The software that comes with the camera is also very easy to use.  A great product all the way around.

Reviews.Title: Definitely worth the price
Reviews.Author: Pam L.
Reviews.Content: I read and researched everything that I could find on cameras like this. I actually had the choice down to the Canon SX210 and this camera.  I went to a nearby store and handled both and preferred the feel of the Panasonic in my hand and I definitely did not like the placement of the flash on the Canon.  I was also concerned about being able to place the date on the image and the Panasonic does let you do that.  The manual is online, but simple to understand.  I have now had this camera for a month and it does everything the information/reviews on it says it does.  My pictures and movies are unbelievably clear.  I have turned off the GPS feature totally as I am not traveling in the near future and the battery lasts as would any camera battery.  I have only had to recharge it once in the last month and have used it for pictures and movies.  Turned off, the GPS feature does not seem to drain the battery contrary to the other reviews.  Have no negatives about this camera as of yet.  Easy to use, a great purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great zoom and lens, overall good camera, a few flaws
Reviews.Author: Nancy J. Bochichio "njlbo"
Reviews.Content: Now that I've been using this camera, Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7, for almost 2 months, I can have an opinion about it.  I'm still playing around with the manual modes.Hardware-wise - while the Leica lens is nice and clear, it's the flipside that I am concerned about, and that is whether I will scratch or crack the display (the universal screen protector that I put on it fell off in a few weeks).Pros- great zoom- clear outdoor photos- nice size, easy to hold (but wear the wrist strap!)- turning flash off (or on) is easy- self-timer is easy and fun- has lots of scene modes- has lots of settings on the dial and in the menu- small enough for larger pockets- shoots good video, including zoomCons- indoor photos aren't great - playing around with settings helps, but different indoor lighting requires different settings- focus has been frustrating when trying to capture things like insects, a portion of a design, even people, at times - did not find help with Macro mode- software doesn't work on my Mac (VLC will play the AVCHD movies)- no viewfinderFYI, recording can be in "Motion JPEG" format instead of AVCHD.Bottom line - it's not my DSLR (which doesn't fit in my pocket or zoom greatly), but it's a handy, easy substitute which I recommend to anyone willing to learn its idiosyncrasies...unless you just do outdoor and zoom, in which case you just point and shoot!

Reviews.Title: Great bring-it-anywhere camera
Reviews.Author: Simon Wickes
Reviews.Content: Great little camera to bring with you on hikes, or for any event when you might think twice about bringing something larger and heavier. Standout features for me are the geotagging capabilities from the GPS and the great zoom lens. I wish it had RAW output, but thats a minor complaint from an otherwise superb camera. The HD video is a really nice bonus too. You won't regret getting this!

Reviews.Title: Best Compact Camera with Power Zoom
Reviews.Author: James K Tsang
Reviews.Content: I have no problem with ZS7. I tested with a number of shots, bright background, in-house with no flash, movie, telephoto shots etc. All pictures are clean, sharp and with a lot of details. It is amazing that my Dad could take a 150 feet telephoto shot on a moving dog, usually it is impossible with his age and trembling hands, but the picture is clean and recognizable. The O.I.S system is the best among compact camera.The only problem the I found is the GPS. It seemed useless when you have to wait for 5 minutes before you get locked in with the signals from Satellites, and again no use indoors. So I finally set it to off permanently to save power.I have a Canon G9 too. The speed to focus onto a subject is not as fast as ZS7. I think ZS7 is better and it is much cheaper priced. G9 can produce better color, while the ZS7 color may be off (especially blue) a bit but acceptable. G9 is not as sharp as ZS7, this may be the sharpening applied is more on the latter. This is an advantage to me.Overall, I am very satisfied with this camera, and I would ask anyone to consider Panasonic brand, because they are really pushing to be the number one in this DC competition. They are small compare to many big names like Nikon, Canon etc, and they will be a big name in the near future.

Reviews.Title: Greatest Compact Camera I've Ever Owned!
Reviews.Author: James
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. Not only does it take amazing pictures, but it doesn't take long to learn how to use. The camera is great for people who don't know a whole lot about camera setting and also great for those who know how to set shutter rates and other various more advanced settings. A great buy.

Reviews.Title: excellent relatively little camera
Reviews.Author: David R
Reviews.Content: Without trying to write a technical review, this camera is excellent.  I own a Panasonic Lumix FX-18, an 18x zoom, but wanted one that I could carry in my pocket.  While not tiny, it easily fits in a pocket without bulging.  The shots we took on a recent trip to Aspen, Co were superb.  Much, much better than any 3x zoom for versatility.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera with excellent video
Reviews.Author: jsh1120 "jsh1120"
Reviews.Content: Was looking for an update of a point and shoot camera and to substitute for a little used video camera. The ZS7 is an excellent choice. Great wide angle and telephoto capabilities. Easy to use for my wife who has little patience with multiple settings and still fun for me as a gadget fanatic. Takes excellent photos and more than passable video.

Reviews.Title: Good camera..but not great
Reviews.Author: Mathan Arulanandam "matbhuvi"
Reviews.Content: I moved from Canon Powershot S2IS (5MP camera) to ZS7.Let me come straight to the pointPros:- I really love the day time outdoor picture quality.- GPS is really fun. When i loaded the photos to picasa, i was thrilled to see that picasa showed the photo location on google maps- iAuto is really good. It has a very good face detection. Settings it choose based on the location, lighting is really good. I hardly need to switch to manual. Way better than my older Canon's auto mode where i used manual mode most of the time.- Very very good video quality. Even though the pictures are really bad under low light, video quality is really good under low light. I am throwing away my 3CCD panasonic camcorder.- Awesome 12x zoom in this compact frame.- Beautiful coverage with the wide angle lensCons:- Picture quality drastically reduces with light. Really bad low light performance. As i come from a 20MP/cm2 (S2IS) camera to this 50MP/cm2, i can very easily notice the difference in quality when the picture is taken on cloudy days or night time without flash.- The software came with it is a joke. I am using picasa for photos. I am directly copying the video folders to my PC using a SD card reader.This is strictly a great outdoor camera. If you come from a old style camera with high pixel density, you will be disappointed with the low light performance. But this handy guy can replaced my bulky camera and bulky camcorder during our family vacation trips. So four star from me.

Reviews.Title: Excellent pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Hannes
Reviews.Content: I've been satisfied with this camera. It takes good quality pictures in various light conditions.A great product at reasonable price.

Reviews.Title: Don't buy this camera
Reviews.Author: Rickinmn "RickinMN"
Reviews.Content: This camera takes wonderful pictures. But Panasonic has not been honest in describing the GPS function. You cannot turn off the GPS. It ALWAYS drains the battery, even with the GPS turned OFF and the camera turned OFF. Plan on a dead battery within a week of charging--even if you haven't used the camera. Panasonic has a simple solution for the problem--remove the battery from the camera every time you're done shooting. OR, leave it in and just accept that it might be dead when you want to use. That's the advise of the SUPERVISOR at Panasonic after I escalated the case. The owners's manual doesn't tell you that. In fact, the manual says that when the GPS is turned off, it stops trying to position. What it doesn't tell you is that it's STILL using power. There is no way to win on this. Buy a different Lumix and forget about GPS, or be carry lots of extra batteries. The Panasonic engineer who designed this should be looking for a new job.

Reviews.Title: Versatile, feature-laden and capable camera
Reviews.Author: Nebula "Just call me Nebula"
Reviews.Content: I cherished my 7 year old Canon A95 camera for its swing-out LCD screen, easy handling, image quality, manual options and standard AA battery power (I maintain a stash of low cost AA rechargeables). Then it broke down, and I replaced it with the Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 about 6 weeks ago.The ZS7 has no manual focusing, no optical viewfinder, a fixed LCD screen, and a proprietary battery. Its small size makes it more portable but harder to hold than the A95. But none of these are deal-breakers, and in every other respect, it's light years ahead of my old camera. The autofocus works beautifully and can be manipulated to some degree; the fast-reacting "live view" LCD screen works as a highly accurate viewfinder; the LCD is bright, detailed, and 3x the size of the old one; and I bought 2 spare batteries. A compact camera is by definition a trade-off between portability and ergonomics, as human hands aren't going to get any smaller.The ZS7 is a type of point-and-shoot camera known as a travel zoom, which is an especially versatile category. Here are the features I found most useful:* Compactness: This thing can fit in a shirt pocket! It's taking some practice to make sure I hold it where my fingers won't obstruct the flash or sensors, or accidentally press any buttons. I'll figure it out. By the way, the extraordinary zoom range makes it about 1/4 inch thicker than many less capable compact cameras.* Responsiveness: Quick to start up and be ready for use; easy to switch modes and make adjustments; and most important, a short shutter lag (the delay between pressing the button and capturing the image).* Display quality: The 3 inch "live view" LCD is better than most in sunlight, automatically adjusts for different ambient lighting conditions, and can be viewed from almost any angle.* Lens adjustment: It zooms optically from an exceptional 25mm wide angle (great for interiors) to a 300-600mm (depending on mode) telephoto equivalent. Note - these aren't literal focal length numbers; they're equivalent to what they would be if this were a standard 35mm film camera. Most manufacturers express them this way so you can compare apples to apples.* Image quality: The lens is made by Leica, a legendarily high quality and expensive name in photography. The reviews I've read, and my own experience so far, concur that the image quality is very good. It also has image stabilization to compensate for my shaky hands.* Automatic mode: The ZS7 has a mode called Intelligent Automatic, which is an understatement. It does absolutely everything for you (except turn it on, zoom, press the shutter button and wind the cat) without any manual interference. It senses people, scenery, sunsets, closeups, and motion, and changes multiple settings to produce the best results. Many of the online reviews I've read say that they often got better photos on full automatic than by trying to make their own settings. That's confidence-inspiring.* Image size: 12 megapixels vs. 5mp on my previous camera. However, don't let megapixels be a basis for your buying decision; these days you'd be hard pressed to find a digital camera without sufficient resolution. Actually, 5mp is enough for all but the most demanding photographers. I set the ZS7 to take 5mp photos by default; it enables the camera to respond faster and record more images, and it almost doubles the optical zoom range (a Panasonic feature). And the 12mp setting is still there as an option, especially for larger prints.* Built-in GPS! It notes the name and coordinates of the place where the picture was taken, notes the nearest landmark, and adjusts the time zone if necessary. One quibble: when the GPS is turned on, the battery drains more quickly. That's understandable, if disappointing, but you can choose between three GPS modes: The On mode updates your location and drains the battery a bit even when the camera is off; the Flight or Airplane mode turns the GPS off when the camera is off, and the Off mode is completely off.* There are 28 different specialized scene modes; some of the more unusual ones are Soft Skin, Transform (stretch), Self Portrait, Panorama Assist, Food, Candlelight, Hi-Speed Burst, Aerial Photo, Pin Hole, Film Grain, High Dynamic (maximizes detail) and Underwater.* There are several macro modes, a face detection and recognition feature, and up to an hour of continuous video recording (on an 8GB card).Criticisms:* Reds can sometimes appear slightly orange.* The ZS7 tends to produce washed out highlights in contrasty scenes, so I like to compensate by underexposing a bit to maintain highlight detail.* I can't apply exposure compensation in the Intelligent Auto mode, although the setting applies globally in most other modes. So IA mode tends to overexpose.* I still accidentally press the movie record button sometimes; I showed the camera to a friend, and she did it too.* The camera is just a bit too thick for many compact cases. I found one, though.* The USB cable for PC connection has a proprietary plug at the camera end, so it won't be convenient to replace. You can buy a separate flash card reader as an alternative.I've barely scratched the surface of this camera's capabilities, and I'm still discovering new ones. So far, though, I've found little to criticize and much to appreciate. The Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 is a great camera for anyone who wants to take all types of travel pictures and movies with built-in calendar management, GPS information, and automatic time zone adjustment. You'll also be pampered with almost foolproof automation and excellent image quality, and you can develop more sophisticated photography skills at your own pace with manual, shutter priority and aperture priority modes.=== Sept. 10, 2011 - UpdateSome good things about this camera came to light as I used it, and some not so good:+ The camera's Leica lens has incredibly low distortion and flare, even at the widest angle and aperture. It's a pleasure to use.+ The ZS7 produces very little purple fringing (usually visible along the edges of objects against bright backgrounds). I've read that this is due to a special processing algorithm built into the camera.+ Photos generally have very low noise (speckles in darker areas). It's a good thing because I tend to underexpose, which can exacerbate noise.- Panasonic's noise reduction algorithm tends to smear or smudge individual pixels, which can look bad when enlarged a lot. You can combat this effect by turning down the noise reduction, using the highest (12mp) image size setting, and/or turning off the Intelligent Resolution feature. It's a tradeoff.- Sometimes I wish I could focus manually, such as when shooting a Little League game through a chain-link fence. I also wish I could conveniently attach a polarizing filter. I also miss having a viewfinder where the image fills my field of vision.I'm still a big fan of this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Value in a Small Package
Reviews.Author: Knock
Reviews.Content: At first i couldn't believe it when friends and photo staff started recommending that i look at a Panasonic camera.  I have been a Canon man since the late 1960s and only switched when I went digital about 15 years ago.I am an average user with a 'good eye' for photos according to people who see my work.  I waited patiently for digital cameras to get out of the 'novelty' bracket before I bought and the $3000 Nikon I bought no longer was cutting it when compared to my friend's work so I started looking for a replacement several months ago.It was an interesting experience.  The web has become everything I expected of it back in the 1990s.  It gave me a wide range of input on quality, price, usability, performance and more.  In my usual style (I'm an engineer) I also spoke to people whose opinions I respected.  The end result was the Panasonic Lumix shone in all categories that interested me.  I found the performance/price ratio to be particularly appealing, especially when the camera's price started its downward drift common to many hi tech products after they have been on the market for awhile.The size causes me a few minor problems but the big issue for me is that I like a view-finder, especially in strong sunlight.  I always liked the SLR for this reason especially because it gave you a precise preview of your shot.  The camera was so good that I immediately bought a second one for my wife.

Reviews.Title: one of the best pocket camera ever!
Reviews.Author: Kits "Cats"
Reviews.Content: Although not very compact, I'm still consider the camera pocket-able.Moving from D-SLR to P&S; is a big step for me. I'm carefully searching for P&S; camera that produce excellent image quality, great manual control features, great coverage for both wide & zoom reach, sharp, and great deal on price.I was considering LX5/S95 earlier but due to its price, I'm willing to compromise the low light capability with more reach zoom on ZS7.To my surprise, everything that I was hoping for included in this camera. Excellent build quality (much better than my old canon), super sharp lens, full customizable setting, great video performance.Pro :1. Excellent build quality. Metal casing from body to battery door. My old Canon SD800 battery door made from plastic.2. Super sharp lens. tested indoor with maximum zoom level, I was able to get very sharp pictures. Just like pic that came from my canon dslr lens.3. Despite for its limitation, I can set the camera to perform up to my standard. for example, I can set the isomax to 400, therefore I can eliminate the noise issue in low light condition. And many more custom setting to choose from. Of course I still need sturdy hand or use tripod/monopod in this situation.4. Great coverage both wide end and tele zoom. 12x zoom is equal to 300mm lens on DSLR. what a great reach for such small camera!5. Excellent image quality & smart camera. I don't have to decide whether I want to shoot macro, landscape or portrait. the camera can adjust itself depending on your situation. very smart!6. Cool video reproduction w/ stereo sound. Panasonic seems to think outside the box how to overcome the camera limitation. The zoom function for example will move slow during video recording. This allow us to get smoother movement and reduce zoom motor noise. Continuous AF also supported. You can get similar result like the one recorded with camcorder. Worry about the AVCHD lite format? Good news is you can change the video format to motion JPEG which widely used by all video editing software including windows movie maker. For me, I like AVCHD better since I can take full video movie features that this camera promise.7. GPS functionality. automatically tag the photo & videos by detecting point of interest location from around the world. Just make sure you turn off this GPS features if you don't needed as it will drain your battery even when your camera in off position.8. excellent 11 points AF tracking & continuous tracking. This camera also can remember your face (up to 6 faces) and prioritize the focus on these faces.9. Manual depth of field control. Whether you want blur background or sharp landscape shot, everything that you could possibly dream of from DSLR, you can have it in here.10. Various scene selection. some of my favorites: pin hole (vignetting effect), High dynamic (HDR).  Update: Just found other cool things. Some of the scene selections can be applied toward video as well. For example you  can have vignetting effect with desaturated color when recording movies. This is very cool!Cons:1. No manual video control. I wish it has manual aperture control during video recording like LX-5.2. small aperture. If the camera  has larger aperture like f/2.8, it will have better result in lowlight shot.3. Light streak during video recording. Exposing to bright light, the video can produce light streak during recording. This is not the camera fault. It is CCD sensor issue that applied to any camera using the same sensor. Some new camera used backlit MOS sensor to overcome this issue but there is a trade in effect which reduce still shot image quality compare to CCD sensor.  For me I'm still choosing CCD over Backlit-MOS.

Reviews.Title: This is one smart camera!
Reviews.Author: H. Ritchey
Reviews.Content: I purchased my DMC-ZS7 almost a year ago, and have subsequently taken thousands of pictures throughout my world travels - Hawaii, Africa, Europe.My favorite features:GPS - My Panasonic has helped me to remember where each picture was taken with the ingenious GPS function.  The GPS isn't perfect, and does sometimes take a few minutes to upload the new location, especially when you've changed countries, but it makes categorizing pictures so much easier. After a Christmas cruise that featured multiple port calls, I could easily sort my pictures from a cruise by destination, and the GPS tag reminded me of the names of several of the archaelogical sites I'd photographed while listening to the tour guide.  It was much nicer to upload my pictures to Facebook with captions that were informative rather than being left with "this is some place in Greece, but I forget what it was called."Zoom - The 12x Zoom was the second biggest selling feature for me on the camera. I don't want to carry around a full size camera complete with long distance lens, but I like to be able to zoom in to capture details, and this camera seems to offer the best of both worlds. I get a lightweight purse friendly camera that can zoom in for some incredible shots, and the camera is smart enough in the IA function to compensate for zooming in and getting the macro details even on zoom. I've captured photos of butterflies and birds that you would never guess I was twenty feet away and shooting with a point and shoot camera.HD Video - The ability to shoot quality video with the camera allowed me to retire my old video camera, and subsequently cleared out additional space in my go to travel bag - Overland Equipment Special Edition Donner Bag.  With a 16GB SD card, I've never run out of space even while shooting video, high definition shots and shooting for multiple days.  Unlike some other cameras that I tried, the DMC-ZS7 allows you to use the zoom while shooting video.Baby/Pet Function - You can 'teach' your camera to recognize your children or pets, and it will then tag each photo with information about how old your child is in the photo! Makes putting together a baby book that much easier.Scenes - I love the preset scenes to select from, especially the Film Grain and High Dynamic.  With a quick flick of the top dial, you can transition from black and white, to color saturated shots, to normal photographs. I've found the rapid change ability between the scenes allows me to capture the same photographs in multiple different exposures. Very rarely do you find yourself "stuck" with a black and white picture that you wish could have been in color because it is so easy to switch back and forth. I am a photography junky, but have never taken a class, so don't really know much about apertures/exposures/etc, so I really enjoy that the various functions take so much of the guess work out of my hands. My sister has top of the line amateur equipment, and I think my pictures from our Christmas travels turned out fairly comparable, and she lugged around a lot more equipment and spent a lot more time fiddling with her camera in between shots.  For a handy travel camera, I think the Lumix is pretty keen.Image Quality - I've printed out photos up to 8x10 from my DMC-ZS7, and have been thrilled with the quality.If you're looking for a good, smart camera for travels or for documenting your family events, I don't think you can go wrong with the Lumix DMC-ZS7.  Are there cameras out there that will take better quality pictures - probably, especially if you get DSLR camera. However, I've always found that the better pictures are the ones you actually take, and the portability of this camera means that more often than not I have my camera with me and am able to get great pictures at times when I wasn't planning on taking pictures. If you opt for a larger DSLR camera, you are less likely to always carry it with you and find yourself in more of those "Man, I wish I had my camera" moments, while I'll be snapping away with my trusty Lumix.Happy snapping!PS - I would very highly recommend the Digital Matrex Lumix POWER KIT as an additional purchase when you get your camera. The 3rd party batteries have worked like a charm in mine and are significantly cheaper than the Panasonic branded batteries.

Reviews.Title: Finally a great point and shoot camera!
Reviews.Author: Jen
Reviews.Content: I have completed a lot of research on cameras and have had discussions with many photographers.  I first started out with the Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ40 14.1 MP Digital Camera with 24x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD which took great outdoor pictures.  The zoom worked wonderful and I was still able to get crisp shots.  Inside however, the pictures were blurry and poor quality.  After having many discussions with photographers, I think the poor indoor quality was due to me not having patience to learn how to adjust the camera.  With three small kids, I just didn't have the time to spend on learning the camera.  I wrongly then went to the Panasonic G1.  Wow!  This was complex.  I called panasonic to work me through the camera, which got me no where.  Sent it back.  Then went on to the  Fujifilm FinePix S2500HD 12MP Digital Camera with 18x Optical Dual Image Stabilized Zoom.  This by far was the worst of all three.  All pictures were blurry and orange.  I tried every advice given to me.  Changed the ISO, etc.  I call Fuji and we think I had a defective product, returned it.I was debating between the Canon SZ 30 IS (?) and the Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 12.1 MP Digital Camera with 12x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD.  I decided on the Panasonic.  I am so glad I did.  Right out of the box in the IA mode it took great pictures!!!  I had my kids run back and forth, and the shots were good.  The flash was more powerful than the other three cameras (standard flash).  So far, I am very happy with this camera.  I would highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: I really like the camera.  Great Zoom abilities
Reviews.Author: Eric
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera before we went on our dream trip, Rome to Egypt by way of Turkey.  It worked really well.  Many places we went did not allow flash, but I found that the images were captured, even though they were dark...but it was easy enough to lighten them with a photo fix app.  and the images were wonderful.  The zoom worked really well..we could see a close up of the tops of great pyramids!It a little limiting not to have a vew finder when in the bright daylight.  but we managed and did not feel that we missed pictures we wanted.  The movie function is a little difficult to figure out...not inuitive...but I'm hopeful with the manual, I 'll be able to work it out.  You can zoom while taking a video, something we couldn't do with our previous camera.The GPS function is cool, but it takes a lot of energy and having the batteries work for all day was more important than having the GPS on.I recommend a backup battery...I really had no trouble taking pictures all day and never went through the 2nd battery.Some reviews commented on the poor fash, but I really didn't find that an issue.I would recommend the camera.  Read the directions...

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera; Well Worth Purchase Price
Reviews.Author: Rick_ATL
Reviews.Content: This was the first digital camera I've purchased in several years.  Needless to say, the options were almost unlimited.  After reading hundreds of reviews on dozens of cameras, I selected the ZS7.  Wow, what quality for the price!  I am very impressed.  The controls on the camera are easy to use.  The menu selection and layout allows quick changes and adjustments to almost any sort of situation.I do have several suggestions, however: when you order the camera, go ahead and order a second battery.  If you use the video feature a lot, you'll run out of juice fast.  In addition, I like having my camera with me most of the time, in the event I have a need to take a pic.  There's nothing more frustrating than running out of battery power at a critical time.  Having a second battery will help.The second suggestion is to order a mini-HDMI to HDMI cable, so that you can connect the camera to your HDTV.  If you are traveling, and your hotel has an HDTV with HDMI input, you can watch your videos on the screen that is larger than your laptop (if you are the kind of person that brings a laptop on vacation).Thanks to an earlier review here on Amazon, I ordered a Lowepro Rezo 30 case along with my camera.  The ZS7 fits perfectly, and the accessories area can carry an extra storage card and battery.  It's a great value, and I would suggest you buy one as well.  Lowepro Rezo 30 (Black)

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera in the Point and Shoot Category
Reviews.Author: Ashish Agrawal "Ashish"
Reviews.Content: Previously I have owned lots of different point and shoot, Compact and one DSLR camera. It goes without saying that if you are expecting DSLR like picture quality with this camera, please dont fool yourself. But yes, if you compare apple to apple this is in front of the league. I purchased this as a alternate to DSLR as it is really very compact. First I will talk about good things because of which I rated it as 4 stars:1: Compactness with 12~16x optical zoom: This is just amazing. Having this big of a zoom in a dslr will cost you multi grand investment but here you have it handy. Hats off to Panasonic for creating such a compact body.2: Image Stabilization: Again this is Awesome. If I compare this with my old Canon S3IS, this camera is way too good in respect to image stabilization. In other compacts and point and shoot, I observed as you zoom, blurring effect increases, because of hand shakes. I tried clicking the moon at 17x, and to my surprise, it came exactly as i wanted. I am just loving it.....3: N number of options: Although this is a compact camera you have all the manual setting (apart from manual focus). You have bracketing, metering, burst shooting, numerous scene modes..etc etc. List is endless.4: Speed: Again if you compare this camera among its peers, this is pretty fast in focusing and startup. I havent measured it exactly but yes, it starts fast and focuses fast.5: Burst shooting: For action photography, there is a burst mode in Scene category. Here you can choose Image vs Speed priority and go from 6 fps to 10 fps. Obviously the image quality will degrade a bit in 10fps, but you have a option of it. Not sure why (apart from flip action shutter) DSLR's charge 3k to 4k for such a speed.Now lets cover the things which forced me to not rate this camera 5 star:1: Not for low light shooting: This camera gives excellent image quality in day light but literally not the best if you want to use it in low light. Pictures will be grainy and dark. You can try bracketing, but cannot get the exact sharp image.2: Body construction: Specially Battery lid and playback/shooting slider looks bit weak. The Battery lid just looks like made of plastic and can break or crack easily. And once it is gone, not sure how you are going to use the camera after that. Also the lens cover is thin plastic. So if you accidently press the lens cover while pulling the camera from the case, you may end up with just the body without the lens.3: Image Size option in different modes: Here I may want some help from other users. As far as I understood, in iA mode there are very limited Image size options. If I choose .3M which is recommended for web attachments, then images comes out to be very small in size and break if i zoom a bit. Second option in this mode is 5M (not sure if this stands for 5MP); here the images are very big in size (approx 1.8-2.2 MB). Now this is way too much. There should have been an option of 3MP in every mode, so that you end up with image approx 1 MB. So if there is any way to get the image in between of two sizes (other than opening the 5MP image in photoshop and resizing), please let me know.So over all, this is an excellent point and shoot with lots of features.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera with a Few Minor Faults
Reviews.Author: Forrest J. Thiessen
Reviews.Content: I wanted a small point-and-shoot camera with a better-than-typical lens, and the DMC-ZS7 is it--it performs very well and takes great pictures, the larger lens giving it a real advantage over similar cameras I've tried. The GPS is cool, too (although it sucks power like you wouldn't believe).I'd give it 5 stars, except for one very annoying (to me) problem, which I haven't seen covered in other reviews here: incredibly, Panasonic chose to put a non-standard USB jack on the camera. You can only connect it to a computer if you use a special, Panasonic-only cable. I this age when just about every type of consumer electronic device has a regular, mini-, or micro-USB jack, this camera doesn't. They provide a proprietary cable that fits the jack along with the camera... but if you want to connect the camera to a computer to download photos while traveling, say, you have to pack the special cable along with you. And if you loose it, you'll have to order a replacement from Panasonic--no interoperability for you! Oh, and you can't recharge the camera battery through their non-standard USB connector, either.The crazy USB jack isn't a huge issue--my MacBook has a compatible memory card slot in the side, so it's easy to work around it by just moving the memory card back and forth between the camera and my computer when I want to move photos off the camera--but it's the only thing wrong with an otherwise great camera, and it makes no sense to me from a design perspective: it probably cost Panasonic more to use a non-standard jack than a standard one, so why do it, especially on a top-of-the-line camera? Despite this annoyance, I still fully recommend the DMC-ZS7.

Reviews.Title: Unbelievable camera; Excellent picture quality/zoom
Reviews.Author: Sam I Am "soff3"
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a lengthy family trip. I did not want to lug my huge canon SLR and my small compact canon s450 just doesn't give the best picture quality. So after reading about the Lumix series and with some experience with previous lumix models purchased for family/ friends, I bought the Lumix ZS7 which is only a little bit bigger than my ultra compact s450. The pictures are awesome on this camera and the zoom is simply amazing for such a small package. Also, battery life is great although I did purchase a spare. The only downside was the GPS which works well in most places but gets lost in obscure locales. Another plus is the screen which is large, clear and sharp. Menus are intuitive. Video is incredible and frankly, better than my Flip mino HD which I did not even use. You can zoom while videoing which is also nice. My friend purchased a less expensive Lumix model, without the Leica lens and the pictures are noticeably inferior. Also, the screen is not as sharp. This camera is pricey for it's class, but there is a reason it is so popular.

Reviews.Title: Great camera - too bad it broke after 4 months
Reviews.Author: R. Greenlee
Reviews.Content: We got this camera back in March looking for a point and shoot that could take great pictures and also record at least 720P HD video.  This camera fit the bill very well and we have been happy with it.  That is until we took it on vacation and it broke halfway through the trip.  It powers on and looks ok until you try to zoom in/out and try to take a picture at which point it reports a Focus Error.I called Panasonic support and they gave me RMA info to send it back in but the thing I'm most upset with support about is that they will only send me a refurbished unit.  Here I have a 4 month old camera in prestine condition and they want to replace it with a refurbished model in questionable condition.  Very unhapy with this.Like I said..  good camera but not happy with the support experience when it broke.

Reviews.Title: Lots To Love, Great Videos, A Few Reservations
Reviews.Author: Ellen Ripley
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera just about a week and will write a full review when I know how this camera works a little better. I also bought a Canon SD940is. Although I never owned a Canon it was immediately intuitive without any user's manual. I was shooting and taking videos in 10 minutes. This camera, the ZS7 has lots more features, but it lacks the very cool MY COLORS feature of the latest Powershots. The ZS7 is not as intuitive for me to use because it has lots more manual settings and I was turning things on and off like crazy. If I keep it in iA (Intelligent Auto) I get beautiful pictures unless the light isn't very good. The Image Stabilization is spot on. You can download the manual but it doesn't really help much explaining what certain settings do very well and doesn't give help on how to take better pictures using the many adjustments.But I'm writing this preliminary review to address a couple problems I'm experiencing that may cause me to return this camera unless some of you experts can shed some light on my problems. Hope you know the answers.1. I looked at my camera and noticed that the firmware is version 1.0  I went to the Panasonic website and see that there is a ZS7 upgrade to version 1.1 available to download. However it ways for: DMC-ZS7 (Without DMC-ZS7GK). Now I don't know what that GK stands for, but I'm wondering if it's something I should download. I know that there are problems with non OEM batteries when new firmware versions are downloaded. Wondering what to do here?2. During Playback Mode you can set the Auto Rotate function ON and it should rotate the pics on the screen horizontally or vertically as you display your pictures on the screen.(I'm not using Slideshow) The Canon does this perfectly. This does not appear to work on my ZS7 camera at all. Am I doing something wrong? Is the camera broken?3. I have taken quite a few videos, and in some, but not all, of them I can hear a clicking noise while I am recording and also in the playback. I did a test video last night inside the house and zoomed the heck out of the camera and there were no click at all. I have digital zoom turned off. I recorded in M-JPEG. But some other videos I did a couple days ago have a very audible and annoying clicking noise in them throughout.4. I've played around a lot with the menus and taken a lot of videos and in a matter of a few hours my battery is running down to 2 bars. I took some videos one night then did not use the camera for a couple days and when I went to show someone the pictures the battery was dead almost immediately. However, even though I had done about the same amount of videos the Canon was still chugging away and we took a few more videos, took some pictures and did a slide show of my 120 pics and 5 videos and the battery was still full. WOW! (that's wow in a bad way for the ZS7).Please weigh in camera experts and especially ZS7 owners. Thanks.Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 12.1 MP Digital Camera with 12x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Blue)UPDATE 6/30/12: I've owned this camera almost 2 years now and just thought I should report in. This is BEST CAMERA I have ever owned. I take a lot of pictures for e-Bay stuff and with friends and family. I mostly shoot on the auto setting because it creates nearly perfect pictures. Pictures are crisp, clear and properly balanced. You don't even really need any kind of photo editor for this camera except for cropping and adding text. The pictures are that good. Of course, I'm not a professional photographer. Battery life is good although I always carry a spare battery just in case. The only bad thing is the software that comes with it, it's not very good. So I don't use it.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic TZ10
Reviews.Author: Donald Doak
Reviews.Content: Since buying the camera I have taken 2000 pictures and tried about 25% of it's features. This camera is outstanding, batery life is excellent, telephoto is the best so far of all the digital cameras I've had to date. the only thing I do not like is the video button is poorly located for a one hand picture taking, it is located were you thumb rests and is easily pushed by accident. Otherwise I have yet to find any other thing wrong with it. The videos are HD and great, they do use up alot of memory on your SD card which is fine if you use a 2gig card or higher, which I do. The software which comes with the camera allows you to convert the video to MPEG2 so you can watch it with most anything. All in all I rate this camera one of the very best point and shoot digital cameras on the market today.

Reviews.Title: A Quality P&S;
Reviews.Author: Ross
Reviews.Content: Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7 12.1 MP Digital Camera with 12x Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD (Black)The form factor of this camera is great and it has a ton of features and adjustments.  The quality of construction is very good; a metal tripod mount is something you rarely see on a P&S.;  The battery and port doors are much better than what I see on the modern Canon models.  The rear LCD is big and bright.  All of the buttons and switches have a nice feel to them.  Unfortunately it is hard to see the icons on the 4 silver buttons around the menu button.The lens is quite sharp corner to corner at the focals I have tried so far.  I don't see significant CA or significant corner blurring; the lens performance seems to be better than what I've seen with the modern Canon models.  When shooting outdoors the lens is able to resolve very good detail in green grass.  This is something many modern Canon models have trouble with.  The lens stays sharp at the 12x max optical zoom focal.  I also tried the iZoom 16x feature and it worked better than I expected.The iA Full Auto mode seems to work better than Canon's Smart Auto mode. Canon's Smart Auto mode is much more likely to boost the ISO too high and/or pick a shutter speed that is much too slow for a handheld picture.  The ZS7's iA mode usually picks conservative ISO and shutter values.  I've also played with M, S, A, and P and I've tweaked the various "Intelligent" features.  All of these features work great.  The ability to store and retrieve three custom setups is great.  The menu isn't as slick looking as Canon's menus, but it works well and offers a surprisingly large number of features.  My wish list includes:* I wish I had the ability to manually pick from more ISO values.* I wish there was a way to pick the flash shutter speed value without dropping to manual mode.* I wish the flash had more power.* When using the Auto ISO mode I wish the camera would allow the shutter speed to drop to the value I set for the "MIN SHTR SPEED" before raising the ISO.* I wish the lens was F2.8 or better on the wide end.Color, contrast, detail, and sharpness are very good to excellent in bright outdoor light. The default WB setting is a bit on the cool side, which is ok.  Outdoor images taken in bright light look as good as anything I've seen from any other P&S; camera.  The images do show a significant amount of noise in dark areas, even at low ISO.  The ZS7 performs a significant amount of default sharpening even with the "Intelligent Resolution" feature off.  I see more default sharpening with the ZS7 than I do with modern Canon models.  This can be adjusted with "PICT. ADJ", but I've yet to change it.The images get really noisy over ISO 400 unless the scene is extremely bright.  The flash does not have much power and flash shots in a dim room can be pretty noisy.  The flash on my wife's small Canon SD1200 sub-compact has more power than the ZS7's flash.  Flash shots taken with the small Canon SD1200 are usually better than the same flash shot taken with the ZS7.  The small Canon gives off more light and the light does not fall off as much.  I sometimes need to take the ZS7 out of iA mode to get good flash pictures in a dim room.  iA mode will sometimes pick a slow sync scene mode that can blur your shot if you are not using a tripod. P mode takes much more consistent flash shots. The same can be said of the Canon.I've yet to play with PICT.ADJ. or movies, but the GPS seems to work well.

Reviews.Title: I think this is a low quality product and I can argue it because of the following situations:
Reviews.Author: JOSE ARTURO GOMEZ VELASQUEZ
Reviews.Content: I think this is a low quality product and I can argue it because of the following situations:Before the expiration of the warranty, the camera failed and we had to sent it from COLOMBIA to USA IN ORDER TO MAKE EFFECTIVE OUR CAMERA WARRANTY AND THE CASE WAS  REGISTER AT PANASONIC, LIKE THIS:1) warranty for PANASONIC request, before the first year:CAMERA'S PROBLEM INFORMATION.Case No.: 28923597 (number given by the panasonic service)Camera Error: System Error (Focus)CAMERA'S PURCHASE INFORMATION.Order Placed: November 30th 2010Purchase Order Number: 105-3724561-8794631Buyer: Jose Arturo Gómez Velásquez.Price: $ 249.95 USD.2) Request for warranty to PANASONIC (Telephonically, JANUARY 29 DE 2013):The Camera failed again for the same focus problem at January 2013 PANASONIC CALL ( 18002117262, talk to Mr. Jose, who gave me the SERVICE IN SPANISH) AND SAY NO WARRANTY EVEN WHEN THE PROBLEM IT IS THE SAME THAT THE CAMERA HAS BEFORE. THIS CAMERA WAS A CHRISTMAS GIFT FOR MY DAUGHTER IN 2010, MY SON ALSO we had given a Panasonic IN 2007, with similar features, but a previous model (TZ3) PURCHASED IN NEW YORK, AT A VACATIONAL TRIP AT 2007,  AND THE CAMERA  ALSO FAILED IN 2012, MAKING BLUR AND RED PHOTOS WITH Streaks.THEREFORE, I believe that these cameras can have great features which motivate the costumer to buy it but it make NO sense at all to buy them, because they fail really soon, and they became  in a really expensive luxury that it does NOT work properlyJOSE ARTURO GOMEZjose_arturo_gomez_velasquez@hotmail.com57-2-6650559 (COLOMBIA)

Reviews.Title: very disappointing product and customer service
Reviews.Author: lindsay1424
Reviews.Content: I was very excited to purchase this product, and I in fact switched from my usual Canon purchase due to all of the positive reviews. Unfortunately, this product and the Panasonic customer service was a disappointment.Immediately there was a problem with the shutter and the camera had to be replaced; I was of course provided with a refurbished model despite exchange very shortly following purchase (and despite multiple conversations with customer service). The refurbished model had problems within 5 months, with the shudder not opening, and then when it did open, the lens not focusing beyond a blurred mess.I then again called Panasonic, and they refused to replace the camera, citing that it had been too long since the initial purchase (though within the time limit when applied to the refurbished model they had provided me!), but that I could send it in for repair (to be paid for by myself). I went through all of the appropriate channels trying to explain my situation and look for some assistance, but I was met repeatedly by the same repetitive response, cant help you, you'll have to send it in for charged repairs.The entire experience was frustrating and costly, and I will never purchase another Panasonic product.

Reviews.Title: Third time is NOT a charm
Reviews.Author: Stephanie
Reviews.Content: This is my third Panasonic Lumix camera and all three times the camera has broken shortly after the warranty expired Each time the cost of repair is close to the cost of buying a new camera.  I will admit that I think it is a great camera while it is working but am very disappointed that seems to be made to only last about 1 year.  When I spoke to the representatives at Panasonic to explain my disappointment, their only response was "K".  I then said "it seems like you really don't even care about your product" and again the response was "K". I will not be purchasing this brand again.

Reviews.Title: Lens Spots
Reviews.Author: Mr. Stewart E. Gill
Reviews.Content: This is my second Panasonic Lumix camera that has developed spots on the inside of the lens where they cannot be reached without taking the camera apart. The first was a DMC-ZR1, purchased on February 16, 2010. The DMC-ZS7 was purchased on January 18, 2011. Both cameras were handled with great care - never got wet. I notified Panasonic when the first camera developed this problem, but, as it was out of warranty, they offered nothing more than an address to send the camera for repairs, which were almost as expensive as buying a new camera. I notified them of the DMC-ZS7's problem today, but this camera is also out of warranty, so I have low expectations. If Panasonic makes any effort to address my problem, I will update this review. Except for the lens spots, both cameras have performed very well.

Reviews.Title: Not rugged enough for the backcountry
Reviews.Author: BrianD
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera primarily for use when motorcycling in the backcountry.  From the get-go the lens cover has been susceptible to even small amounts of dust.  It would stick closed or partially closed regularly, requiring assistance to open.  Not a big deal when blown out with a can of air regularly.  It did this even when always kept cased and in a plastic bag when not in use.The camera got wet once when in the pocket of my riding jacket in a rain storm.  Not flooded, just damp on the outside, resulting in condensation on/in the lenses.  I set it in a bag of rice for 2 weeks...no go.  Sent it off to be repaired...$180 IIRC.  Worked fine for 3-4 day trips before dying a final time-no image on the display when you try to take a picture.  Display itself works fine...must be in the image capture electronics.
